title: pubs open uk when
story: Prime Minister Boris Johnson confirmed that our locals willafter releasing a statement in the House of Commons.Mr Johnson announced that pubs will be among those allowed to reopen on July  in England.Speaking on LBC news on July , the Prime Minister said: Tomorrow we come to step three of the plan that I set out on May , that everybody, I think, has understood, or huge numbers of people have understood and followed very carefully and very closely.And its because people stuck to that plan that were now able to carefully and cautiously open up hospitality tomorrow.And my message is really for people to enjoy summer sensibly and make sure that it all works.Boozers had to shut back in March, with many issuing concerns they could go out of business.But, in another boost to locals, the two-metre social distancing rule has been reduced to one metre plus - which means one-metre minimum distance when not possible to otherwise.The plus means that the public must also take other precautionary measures to limit any potential spread.Mr Johnson has also revealed pubs will be allowed to serve drinks outside in a bid to boost the economy.Pubs in Northern Ireland opened at pm on Friday, July .Welsh Government plans have revealed that pubs can reopen outdoors on July .The date in Scotland is July  with beer gardens can reopening from July .Matt Hancock confirmed The Suns story that bars and restaurants will have to keep a record of everyone who visits before being served under new plans.Ministers have discussed a guest register will be kept by landlords and managers to help track and trace coronavirus outbreaks.The idea has been used in New Zealand where each venue must record visitors and carry out regular headcounts.Personal details are kept on file for four weeks and are used to contact peopleone of the patrons later is hit with coronavirus.Some pubs have been allowed to partially reopen in June using outdoor market-style stalls.Government officials have previously suggested it could take many months for pubs to reopen - sparking fears for the future of many of the UKs , locals.Top scientists have predicted that the hospitality could start to pick up without triggering a second wave.With all other pubs across England, Wetherspoons will reopen their doors on July .The famous pub chain Wetherspoons shut all their doors on March , but have since revealed their plan to reopen over  pubs across the UK.Wetherspoons has said they are investing £million into this new plan to make sure the new measures keep both their staff and customers safe.Each pub will be temperature checking all their staff before they start their sht, as well as providing them with gloves, masks and protective eyewear for them to wear when working.They have also suggested they will be limiting their menu slightly, as well as replacing all the usual condiments with sachets rather than plastic bottles and create one-way systems in and out of the venues.The Sun was given a first glimpse of the new layout as it was revealed there will be screens, posters and floor markings.There will be separate exits and entrances, and tables will not be positioned to abide by social distancing rules.The two-metre social distancing rule has been reduced to one metre plus - which means one-metre minimum distance when not possible to otherwise.The plus means that the public must also take other precautionary measures to limit any potential spread.The social distancing measures implemented would require drinkers to order their booze remotely via an app, with the punter then having to collect their drinks from the bar to minimise contact between staff and customers.Bar staff will have to wear masks and gloves at all times while working.It’s unlikely you’ll be able to simply walk into a pub on the spur of the moment and have a pint, certainly in the first few days of reopening.Drinkers have been warned that you will have to book a table beforehandyou want to go to the pub on July .You can support your local by heading for a pint or some food when they reopen.You can also join campaigns like Long Live the Local, who are trying to get the government to freeze beer duty to support pubs when they finally reopen.The team is also working on some new plans to try and mitigate the massive toll our boozers are paying for coronavirus.Budweiser is selling gt cards for pubs here, which they then match as a donation to your pub.Landlords can add their pubs to the scheme too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: epstein dalton school teacher
story: The convicted pedophile, , who died in a jail cell last year, abused hundreds of young women while using his money and power to evade prosecution for years.After the academically bright Epstein left school at age  – he skipped two grades – he attended two prestigious universities in Manhattan before inexplicably dropping out of both.But the future-Wall Street financier talked his way into a job at the The Dalton School in  teaching Math and Physics to the children of wealthy New York families.It later emerged that he lied on his job application to gain access to the girls at the exclusive academic institution.Epstein also benefited from a loosening of Daltons previously strict codes of conduct enabling the young sociopathic teacher to prowl among the students outwith classes.Former pupils claim Epstein inserted himself into social groups and even attended parties with the children – behaviour which was deemed by some to be “wrong” and “inappropriate.”Dalton alumina Scott Spizer told the New York Times: I can remember thinking at the time this is wrong.He was much more present amongst the students specically the girl students, during non-teaching hours...it was kind of inappropriate.Another former pupil Mark Robinson, who was never directly taught by Epstein, said other pupils praised the sex offenders teaching abilities, particularly in private tutorials, but found his behaviour outside the classroom “creepy.”He told Sun Online: “The perception of Epstein was that he was a twenty-something who preferred hanging out with teenage students and acted like them, even in school.“Additionally, the students that he was most often seen spending time with were freshman and sophomore girls.“Most of the other students saw this not as being cool, but as just plain creepy.”It is unknown whether Epstein assaulted any of his students while at Dalton - although he was asked that very question in a  legal deposition.He was asked did you have any sexual contact with any of the girls that you were teaching at Dalton But rather than saying no, Epstein replied: While I was a teacher When he said he had not abused any of girls when he was working there, he was then askedhe had sexual intercourse with them when he left Dalton.To that question, Epstein replied: Not that I remember.The pedophile also said he taught “mostly old” girls aged “ and .”In , Epstein was fired from Dalton by then-head Peter Branch who later said: It was determined that he had not adequately grown as a new teacher to the standard of the school.However, the con artist managed to “schmooze” his way into another top job, this time on Wall Street with investment giant Bear Stearns.During a parent-teacher meeting, Epstein wowed one dad with his intelligence prompting him to tell the banks CEO Alan Greenberg: Youve got to hire this guy.Greenbergs daughter Lynne Koepell relayed the story to the Miami Herald, saying: “That was Jeff. He was very smart and he knew how to woo people, how to schmooze...If that was his plan, it worked.Sun Online has approached The Dalton School for comment.GOT a story  EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: when nightclubs music venues reopen uk
story: Many businesses however have had to remain closed - and the list includes nightclubs and music venues.From July , hotels, pubs, libraries, hairdressers, and caravan sites will be able to open.However, nightclubs, gyms and spas will stay closed as they pose too much of a risk due to the close proximity of people in these spaces.The full list of businesses that have to remain closed are:The UKs May  three-step plan said that reopening venues whose “core purpose is social interaction ... may only be fully possible signicantly later depending on the reduction in the numbers of infections.”The government is cautious as there was a coronavirus spike in South Korea as soon as they reopened nightclubs in late April and had to shut them down again after only two weeks.In Germany, where the virus is almost under control, the ban on nightclubs will last until July  at least, while gatherings of more than , people arent happening until October .Gigs and concerts are unable to take place unless they are being live-streamed due to the risk of people singing and passing on the virus.Open-air concerts will likely be the first to reopen as they are better ventilated and fields have much more space than clubs.The Government plan says: “Reopening outdoor spaces and activitiescomes earlier in the roadmap because the risk of transmission outdoors is signicantly lower.”Some music venues have already started hosting performances for broadcast.In June Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden shared this five-step plan for the gradual reopening of music venues, although there are no dates as to when these steps can be taken.Dowden said: I am determined to ensure the performing arts do not stay closed longer than is absolutely necessary to protect public health.The Government hasnt said much about what social distancing measures will be in place for gigs and concerts, but the chances are that the bar will be socially distanced the same way it will be in pubs.It is highly likely that there will be reduced capacities and space between attendees, such as spaced seating in venues like Wembley.Capacity will likely be increased over time as the R value goes down in the local area, but that all depends on how things go.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit news latest eu live
story: Talks in Brussels between Boris Johnsons Europe adviser David Frost and the EU led by Michel Barnier were due to continue into Friday.But Mr Frost said talks will continue next week in London.Michel Barnier accused Britain of showing a lack of respect for his demands.He said there are still serious ergences between both teams as the latest round of negotiations ended in deadlock.This comes as Parliament passed the Immigration Bill last night that would end the UKs Freedom of Movement with the European Union, which will see EU nationals and their families will be subjected to UKs immigration laws.Follow our Brexit live blog below for all the latest updates…The United Kingdom is in talks to join the EU’s vaccine plan.Officials said No  is assessing whether the bloc’s bargaining powers with big drugs companies could outweigh the desire to sever ties with Brussels.A spokesperson for the European Commission told the financial times: “We have reached out to the UK, inviting it to express its interestit wants to participate in the joint EU approach established by the vaccine strategy.“Discussions are now ongoing with the UK.” Boris Johnson has said failure to reach a trade deal in Brexit talks could be a “very good option.”Speaking on LBC earlier today Mr Johnson said: “We now need to make sure we get a good deal. I think actually – I’ve had some very good conversations – with friends and colleagues around the EU. I’m a bit more optimistic than Michel [Barnier] is there.”He added: “I just think there’s a good agreement to be reached, but obviouslywe can’t then we will have the very good option also of an Australian-style arrangement.”Boris Johnsons economic investment response to the coronavirus crisis has been criticised by Tory former deputy prime minister Lord Heseltine.Lord Heseltine told BBC Radio s Today programme: #What we have is a twin crisis, which is the crisis of the corona epidemic# and it is over with the crisis of Brexit.#It is a crisis of unprecedented scale and it is going to get worse.#So, the question really is how is the Government responding, how should it respond #And I have to say I was deeply disappointed in the speech the Prime Minister made in Dudley.#It was simply the sort of speech with a lot of proposals which were remarkably similar to what all governments have done faced with rising unemployment.#They announce packets of money in housing and transport and repairs for the health service# but they lack the one thing that is essential, and that is the local enthusiasm, energy and enterprise.#Image: AFPA number of destinations favoured by Brits have been left off the quarantine-free air bridge list today.Hotspots not on the list include:Britain and Brussels will face off over who has the final say in the proposed £bn merger between Virgin Media and O.It comes as the UKs Competition and Markets Authorityis expected to ask the EU’s competition watchdog to hand over control of the review. It will argue that the merger only affects UK customers, the Financial Times reports.The CMA told the newspaper: “This important merger will only impact consumers in the UK and since any review will likely conclude after the transition period, it is only right for the CMA to request it back now.”Its understood, however, that the EU may want control of the process because Brussels has historically overseen telecoms deals.The Government has this afternoon announced the countries on its air bridge list.There are a number of countries now not subject to the -day quarantine.The list includes:More on that last blog post.OneWeb # which has its headquarters in London # will complete the construction of a constellation of Low Earth orbit satellites providing enhanced broadband and other services to countries around the world.Business Secretary Alok Sharma has spoken about the deal.He said: #This deal underlines the scale of Britains ambitions on the global stage.#Our access to a global fleet of satellites has the potential to connect millions of people worldwide to broadband, many for the first time, and the deal presents the opportunity to further develop our strong advanced manufacturing base right here in the UK.#In a statement, OneWeb # which has its manufacturing base in Florida # said the deal would enable the company to emerge from bankruptcy with a #robust foundation# to continue its commercial operations.The th hour bid to acquire a stake in the firm was reportedly signed off last week by Boris Johnson and Chancellor Rishi Sunak.The Prime Ministers official spokesman said the deal will #allow the UK to explore other potential strategic opportunities working with our international allies# after Brexit. The Government has taken a major stake in the failed satellite company OneWeb, in a drive to develop a sovereign UK space capability.The UK is part of a consortium with Indias Bharti Global, which won a bidding war for the company, which went bankrupt earlier this year while trying to develop a space network to deliver broadband.Ministers hope it will compensate for the loss of access to the EUs Galileo programme in the wake of Brexit.The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy said the UK and mobile operator Bharti are each investing  million US dollars , with Britain acquiring a #signicant equity stake# in the company.Officials said the deal would put the UK at the #cutting-edge of the latest advances in space technology#.The England and Wales Cricket Board has approved an increase in overseas players in domestic cricket from next year and will now allow two per side in four-day and -over cricket.Teams are currently allowed to field only one imported player, though foreign-born players with British passports and those on Kolpak registrations have not counted towards the allocation.The effects of Brexit mean Kolpak deals will be terminated at the end of the postponed  campaign meaning those players # as well as those who have had deals cancelled this summer due to the coronavirus pandemic # will now have a greater chance to earning deals.The move was recommended by the performance cricket committee, chaired by Sir Andrew Strauss.Products from Japan or South Korea would be stamped “Made in Britain”, under Boris Johnson’s plan to save the domestic car industry after Brexit.The proposal is an attempt to prevent punishing tarfs driving away the likes of Nissan and Toyota.One trade expert has said the plans will sound “ridiculous” to voters who were promised huge benefits from leaving the EU.Speaking of Nissans threat to leave the UK after Brexit, Alan Winters, professor of economics told The Independent: “We know that the Japanese are wondering whether they would stay around.“Brexit is going to be bad news for jobs in lots of dimensions. In this one dimension, the British proposal would help to head off some of those losses.”And Dr Peter Holmes, reader in economics, said: “What the UK government is seeking from the EU on rules of origin is unprecedented.“To the average Brexit supporter this approach may sound ridiculous and not part of any deal they voted for, but without it Japanese car plants risk facing  per cent tarfs on cars made in the UKthey use engines, gearboxes or other components made in Japan.”German Chancellor Angela Merkel made her first public appearance wearing a mask today # after dismissing accusations of hypocrisy earlier this week for not wearing one.Merkel entered the Bundesrat, the upper house of parliament, wearing a black mask marked with EU.de, a website dedicated to Germanys six-month presidency of the European Union which started on July .Merkel, whose government has made wearing a mask compulsory in some public places, was asked by a journalist at a news conference on Monday why she had never been seen wearing a mask in public.The chancellor responded that she did not need to wear a mask when she was observing social distancing rules, but did so when she could not, for example during private shopping trips when she was not in the public eye.Image: APThe European Commission has given conditional approval for the use of antiviral remdesivir to treat coronavirus – days after the U.S. bought up almost all stocks.The EU executive said the drug, produced by Gilead Sciences Inc, was the first medicine authorised in the EU for treating Covid- following a “rolling review” which began in April.The Commission is in negotiations with Gilead to obtain doses for the  EU countries.However, that may prove dficult after the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services announced it had secured all of Gileads projected production for July and  per cent of that for August and September.Tomorrow is Super Saturday in England as the lockdown eases.So which businesses are allowed to reopen European Union foreign ministers will discuss Hong Kong at their next meeting, German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said today, after China unveiled a national security law, which the West says threatens freedoms in the city.Chancellor Angela Merkel earlier she feared that Hong Kongs autonomy was being #eroded#.She said Germany will raise issues such as human rights with China during its presidency of the EU.Image: APGerman Chancellor Angela Merkel is pushing for a quick agreement on a recovery fund aimed at pulling the European Union out of the coronavirus recession, arguing that every day counts.Germany took over the rotating EU presidency for six months on Wednesday. That gives it a key role in cajoling others in the -nation bloc to compromise on the recovery fund and the EU budget for the next seven years.European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has invited Merkel and top EU officials to a meeting on July  to take stock of progress and prepare the negotiations.#The road is stony and a lot of good will and readiness to compromise from all sides will be required to achieve our aim,# Merkel told the upper house of Germanys parliament in a speech setting out her priorities for the EU presidency. #In view of the current economic development, time is pressing and every day counts.#Image: EPAThe plunge in euro zone business activity caused by lockdowns imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus eased sharply last month as more businesses reopened and people ventured out, a survey showed on Friday.Around  million people have been infected by the virus globally, but as the number of daily reported cases has fallen across much of Europe, governments have loosened restrictions on peoples movement.To support ravaged economies the European Central Bank expanded its pandemic-related bond purchases to a total of . trillion euros last month.More now from the PMs interview with LBC this morning.Askedthe Government was being disrespectful of EU rules, Mr Johnson replied: #No, not remotely.#However, he says it would be wrong for the UK to continue to comply with EU laws or #hand over our amazing fish stocks#, adding: #Were not going to do that#.#We now need to make sure that we get a good deal,# he said. #Im a bit more optimistic than Michelis there.#There is a good agreement to be reached, but obviouslywe cant, then we will have the very good option also of an Australian-style arrangement.#Australia does not have a comprehensive trade agreement with the EU. Much of EU-Australia trade follows default World Trade Organisation rules, though specic agreements are in place for certain goods.Prime Minister Boris Johnson said this morning hes more optimistic than European officials that a post-Brexit trading deal can be struck.But he also said Britain could leave the bloc without a comprehensive agreementneeded.Mr Johnson says hes #more optimistic# than EU negotiator Michel Barnier, who said this week that serious ergences remained and Britain needed to respect the EUs position. The PM saidno deal was struck then an #Australia-style# arrangement would be a #very good option#.Britain left the worlds largest trading bloc on January  but remains a member in all but name until year end. Image: APDavid Starkey is facing a backlash after he said slavery was not genocide because there are so many damn blacks still around.The historian made the comments during an online interview with Brexit campaigner Darren Grimes for YouTube channel Reasoned UK.Former Chancellor Sajid Javid has criticised him over his remarks.Mr Javid said: #We are the most successful multi-racial democracy in the world and have much to be proud of.#But David Starkeys racist commentsare a reminder of the appalling views that still exist.#Fitzwilliam College at Cambridge University said they would be considering Starkeys position as an honorary fellow as a result of his comments.In a statement, the college said they will #not tolerate racism#, adding that his comments are #indefensible#.Justice Secretary Robert Buckland says its #absolutely right# to overhaul the court system after Brexit.Mr Buckland said: #Since leaving the EU we are no longer bound by European laws, and it is absolutely right that British courts have the final say on legal disputes.#We will work with judges and the legal sector to decide exactly which courts should have the power to depart from retained EU case law and will set out our plan in due course.#Any changes would need to be put into law first.The Government has launched a consultation on plans for UK courts to have the final say on legal disputes after Brexit.Officials are asking the judiciary, lawyers and business to comment on the reforms which will decide which British courts have the power to depart from EU case law.At present, only the UK Supreme Court and the High Court of Justiciary in Scotland will have this power from December .Under proposals set out by the Justice Secretary Robert Buckland, more courts and judges in the country would be able to reconsider cases on matters like borders, taxes and fisheries and make the final decision.The Government hopes this will allow cases to progress quicker.In slightly dferent news, Brits can go on holiday to France, Germany, Spain and Italy from tomorrow.Its been announced that people from England will be able to fly to around  countries without needing to quarantinetheyfrom July .However, the new rules will not apply to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland after officials there decided to use a dferent measure to assess the safety of other countries.Heres the full story.The European Union re-opened its borders this week to people from  countries including Canada, Japan, South Korea and Morocco # but not the U.S. The European Union must speak with one voice to Chinait wants to achieve ambitious deals that secure the blocs interests, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said today.It comes as she voiced concerns over a new Chinese security law in Hong Kong.#In order to have successful relations with China and to represent our European interests effectively, Europe must speak decisively with one voice,# Merkel told Bundesrat upper house. #Only together the  EU member countries have enough weight to achieve ambitious deals with China.#She added: #Based on an open dialogue we also speak about the rule of law and human rights as well as the future of Hong Kong where we are concerned that the important principle of one country, two systems is being eroded.#So: whats next Well, the talks will resume next week in London # and negotiators will be hoping for more agreement.It had been hoped the face-to-face meetings # agreed following a high-level conference call last month between Boris Johnson and the European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen # would inject new momentum into the process.Mr Johnson has been adamant he will not allow the discussions to drag on into the autumn, arguing that British businesses and citizens need certainty on the way forward before then.Butthe two sides cant reach a deal by the end of the year, it means Britain will leave the single market and the customs unions without any agreement on future access.Weve covered David Frosts reaction to the new talks.His EU counterpart Michel Barnier said that while Brussels had engaged #constructively#, officials needed to see an #equivalent engagement from the UK side#.#Our goal was to get negotiations successfully and quickly on a trajectory to reach an agreement,# he said.#However, after four days of discussions, serious ergences remain.#He said the EU side had #listened carefully# to British concerns, but again made clear there could be no deal without agreements on fisheries and the so-called #level playing# requiring the UK to follow EU standards infor continued access to the single market.#We will continue to insist on parallel progress on all areas,# Mr Barnier said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sir keir starmer leo mckinstry labour out of touch
story: And this decline in popularity is made all the starker by Labour’s revival under new leader Sir Keir Starmer. Until his recent election the Tories had it easy, confronted by an opposition led by Marxist radical Jeremy Corbyn, whose incompetence was matched by his extremism. But Sir Keir is a far more formidable opponent. He is sharp where Corbyn was dim, pragmatic where Corbyn was dogmatic.Corbyn constantly pandered to the left-wing fringe because he was part of it. But Sir Keir has just proven his toughness by sacking leadership contender Rebecca Long Bailey from the shadow cabinet, after she expressed her support for actor Maxine Peake who used a newspaper interview to peddle conspiracy theories about the Israeli secret service. Corbynista zealots were appalled, moderates celebrated.Furthermore, the dismissal of Long Bailey was just part of a systematic removal of hard Left influence in the party.Much to the fury of left-wing agitators, Starmer yesterday dismissed calls for the police to be “defunded” in the wake of anti-racism protests. Emphasising his past work with the police as Director of Public Prosecutions, he labelled such demands as “nonsense”. Out are Corbyn allies like Jennie Formby, the former General Secretary. And in comes the new chief David Evans, described by admirers as “a stanch opponent” of the hardliners.According to the latest polls, the British public is warming to the new Labour leader. In one survey last week,  per cent expressed a preference for him as Prime Minister, two points ahead of Boris Johnson.Interviewed by the BBC on Sunday, former leader Ed Miliband joined in the cheer-leading, saying: “I never had his approval ratings. I think he has made a great start.”Yet it would be wrong for Labour supporters to be carried away. Sir Keir might be a better leader than Corbyn and Miliband, but those two set the bar very low. The truth is that Labour still has a mountain to climbStarmer is to become Prime Minister. His party is still a deluded rabble, dominated by the worst kind of toxic identity politics, contempt for Britain and student union dogma. Labour is ready for neither victory at the ballot box, nor for the governance of our country.Parallels are sometimes drawn with the situation now and that of , when John Major’s Government was engulfed by the financial crisis of Black Wednesday five months after winning the General Election against Neil Kinnock’s Labour. But the huge dference is that Labour was on the advance, having won a further  seats at the election. Power was almost within the party’s grasp, given that Major only had a tiny majority. But today, Labour is still reeling from the humiliation it suffered last December, when it lost  seats, the biggest loss for any opposition in a century. Moreover, the party is in the wilderness in Scotland. Once Labour’s Caledonian fortress, the party has just one MP there.In total, the Conservatives have no fewer than  more MPs than Labour.That means the job that now faces Starmer is daunting. To be the biggest party, Labour would have to make  net gains from the Tories on a swing of  per cent. Even in the phenomenal landslide of , the swing to Tony Blair was only . per cent.And there is not the slightest sign of that happening at the moment, in spite of all the Government’s recent problems. It is a remarkable fact that the latest two opinion polls both show that the Conservatives, after ten years in office with a very mixed record, are still seven points ahead of Labour.Indeed, there is even a danger that Labour could slip back further. A recent internal review by the party into the disastrous  defeat warned that a further  seats in Labour’s heartlands could be vulnerable on a very small swing to the Tories.The central problem for Starmer is that his party, fixated by fashionable theories of social justice, has alienated its traditional voters. It will take more than the sacking of Rebecca Long Bailey or reassuring words about the police to bring them back. As the sensible former MP Natascha Engel wrote this month, Labour must recognise how far it “has shted from it core. If it wants to sht back again, the party will have to find the right road and prepare itself for a very long walk.” But the journey has barely begun. A party that is willing twice to elect Jeremy Corbyn as its leader is not going to change overnight.In reality, Labour remains gripped by far Left ideology, as shown by its eager embrace of the cultural revolution. Decent, patriotic working-class voters, once the bedrock of the Labour movement, are bound to be repelled by the endless posturing against Britain or the police or family le or even common sense. Despite the change of leadership, the insanity remains. At the weekend, Labour front-bencher Lloyd Russell-Moyle was forced to apologise after disgracefully attacking JK Rowling for using her own experience of domestic sexual assault as “a justication for discriminating” against transgender campaigners.In the same vein, senior Labour MP Dawn Butler recently declared on Good Morning Britain that “a child is born without sex”, a piece of biological nonsense that is about as sane as saying the Earth is flat. The atmosphere of a cult still hangs over the party. The lunatic Left has certainly not gone away, as reflected in MP Richard Burgon’s celebration that teaching unions thwarted “Tory attempts to force schools to re-open. When the row about statues was at its most hysterical, Lisa Nandycalled for imperialist murals to be removed from the magnicent interior of the Foreign Office. Similarly, the Nottingham MP Nadia Whitthome, sounding asshe lived in an occupied country, expressed her thrill at the movement to topple monuments of the past: “I celebrate these acts of resistance.”Sir Keir is not the figure likely to win back the traditional working-class, particularly not in the Red Wall seats of the Midlands and the North. This is, after all, a figure who used to edit a radical magazine called Socialist Futures, who built his reputation as a metropolitan-based human rights lawyer, who presided over the Crown Prosecution Service when it gained notoriety for its failure to take a tough stance on crime, and who battled ferociously for a second referendum on Brexit. For all the ordinariness of his upbringing as the son of a toolmaker and a nurse, he is now the personication of the North London liberal elite. Moreover, he lacks both authority and charisma. With his strangulated vowels and permanently anxious expression, he frequently sounds like a teacher who is surprised at this promotion to be head of department.The political landscape could have changed dramatically by , when the next election is due. Britain may have enjoyed a strong economic recovery. The culture war may have petered out. Public services may have been reformed. title: uk lockdown rules july 4 super saturday independence day
story: The day has been dubbed Super Saturday or the UKs Independence Day, but what are the new rules from July  ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAs businesses reopen from July , there are a number of rules that they will have to adhere to in order to keep staff and customers safe. Below are the rules you should keep in mind. The PM announced that the two-metre rule would be reduced to  metre plus in England meaning people should stay  metres away where possible - or stay  metre away and have other measures such as face masks to help lower the risk.People will be able to meet with two households after July . This can include one of your support bubblesyou live alone and will be able to meet up both indoors and outdoors.You will not be allowed to stay overnight with members from two or more other households.Cinemas in England will be able to reopen on July .Limited tickets will be available at screenings as there must be at least three seats used to separate households.Pick-and-mix sweet sections will be closed.Contactless payments will be encouraged in venues in order to limit contact with staff.Cinemas will also be expected to introduce staggered film start times to enable extra cleaning between screenings and a focus on online booking.Plastic screens will also be installed at key contact points, such as till areas.From July , many places of worship will be open to worshippers.It will be up to the place of worship to decide the capacity of each venue. Social distancing must be adhered to with a space between each worshipper. Staggering entry times to the places of worship will allow people to stay distant along with one-way travel routes.All prayer mats and service sheets that were previously communal will now have a one-time use.Weddings will be able to restart from July - but they wont be quite the same and people will only be allowed  guests at the ceremony.Dferent households are expected to stand two-metres apart even at the top of the aisle.Millions of people shielding in England will be advised to spend more time outside of their homes from July .According to the government website, people shielding from the virus can meet up in groups of up to six people outdoors and form a support bubble.The shielding support package will last until the end of July when people will no longer have to shield from the virus. Campers can rejoice as campsites will be able to open from July  - as long as communal spaces remain clean and safe.Campsites, along with caravan parks, hotels, BBs and holiday lets are to reopen from July  and people will be allowed to travel to their second homes to stay overnight.This includes one other household, meaning two households will be able to go on holiday together.Venues are being encouraged to be table-service only, and have guests order drinks and food through an app where possible.Broadcasts that gather larger crowds that yell at a TV are banned. Loud music will also be banned to stop people having to shout to be heard by their friends.The guidance warns venues they should not permit live performances, including drama, comedy and music, to take place in front of a live audience.Venues are being encouraged to use disposable condiment packets where possible to limit the spread of germs via surfaces.Cutlery wont be laid out on tables unless people order food either.The guidance says businesses should help the NHS Test and Trace system by keeping a registry of patrons contact details for at least  days in case of an outbreak.Pubs and restaurants will have to reduce the number of people in venues at any one time to allow for social distancing - but also to discourage public transport use.The new rules will ban groups of more than  people to form.Toilets which have been closed throughout the coronavirus crisis will reopen in pubs, restaurants and public places.But they will have to be subject to strict hygiene restrictions and extra cleaning.Libraries will reopen from July  with people advised to follow social distancing measures.The government hasnt specied how staff and visitors will stay safe in libraries just yet.However, reopening will happen in phases based on public health guidance and risk management.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leicester landlords scrap reopening coronavirus
story: Barely a mile away on the other side of the ‘border’, another publican gets ready to welcome customers for the first time in three months – but will have to bar any from the neighbouring village.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThis is Leicester, the first UK city to face a local lockdown to stave off a second wave of coronavirus.While health authorities scramble to control the outbreak, the city has been literally split.The border of the new quarantine zone means some residents can head back to the boozer, get y barnets cut and enjoy sleepovers from tomorrow – but their neighbours must stay at home.Struggling landlords have had to cancel long-awaited reopening parties – and watch as watering holes just down the road throw open their doors.Kim Thornley, the landlady at The Railway Inn in Glenfield, broke down in tears as she told The Sun Online how litres of beer would now go to waste after her preparations went down the drain.She said: “It’s just really dficult – financially and mentally.“For  weeks I was fine, thinking ‘we’ll do this and that’.“We’ve done ten weeks of decoration and upgrading everything to reopen – then you get the bombshell.”And she said the bills were still piling in – with her pub only able to seat  instead of its usual  when it eventually is able to reopen under the social distancing guidelines.Now, food will be frozen with Kim attempting tothe beer to the brewery for “other pubs that will need it” until she can finally reopen.In the neighbouring village of Kirby, just outside the lockdown zone, the Royal Oak is getting ready to take bookings.But it will have to ask customers to bring ID with their address on it as anyone from the other side of the ‘border’ – less than a mile away – is barred.Landlady Sarah Flavell said: We’ve just been worried because before when there were other pubs, people would have gone to their own locals.Now it’s just going to encourage people to come to our pubs and I can’t take that risk of not being able to man it and control it.”Health authorities are currently scrambling to figure out just why Leicester has been so badly hit by the bug, with outbreaks at food and clothing factories and in households with several generations living under one roof.The city now accounts for around  per cent of new infections in the country after a whopping  new cases were recorded since mid-June.The Government has said it will review the restrictions in two weeks as they drew up a border around the city to control the infection.But that feels like a letime for publicans – and thirsty locals – who have been waiting more than three months to meet pals for a drink.Facing two more weeks under lockdown, Leicester local Ms Thornley, , who has been at the Railway for  years, said: “We were all geared up and now we have to ride it out again.“It’s devastating.“If everyone had of done what they should have done, we wouldn’t have been in this position.”And on the other side of the border, Ms Flavell said the lockdown had put even more pressure on her business.She said: “I think it’s ridiculous to be honest, I wish they put us all in lockdown, the whole of Leicestershire.“It would have made it a whole lot easier and everybody would have been in the same boat.“Now people from Leicester will just go to other places. If we were the only pub in eight miles that is open, that’s just asking for trouble.”The Plough Inn in Ratby, another village just outside the lockdown, will also ask customers to bring photo ID with their address to gain entry.In a notice on Facebook, they added: “We ask those who live within the Lockdown Boundary to please not attempt to gain entry.“We are sorry we are having to exclude you, but I am sure you will understand, we have to take the safety of our customers and staff seriously, we are taking this measure purely on safety grounds.”“These are strange times,” it added.Police across the country have said they are bracing themselves for “two weeks of New Year’s Eves” to hit when doors open on July .And for some, the decision to remain in lockdown has taken away the pressure of Super Saturday.Tony Marriott, the landlord at the Nags Head, also in Glenfield, said that in some ways, he was glad to stay in lockdown for another two weeks.He said: “It’s given us a bit more time to figure out how people will fit in.“We were apprehensive anyway opening on Saturday.“I feel for the pubs opening – there are going to be a lot of people trying to get into those places.“We just want everybody to be safe.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: super saturday terrible thursday coronavirus cases spike
story: What happens is this. Using your skill and ingenuity, you have to predict which town or city will be the next to be put on special measures .⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesTowns and cities where people haven’t been behaving themselves.Right now, it’s Leicester in the sin bin. They are a very community-minded bunch and couldn’t resist going out to meet each other. So there’s a Covid spike.Experts reckon the next place to cop it will be Doncaster. They’re a friendly bunch there, too. But I reckon there’s a decent outside chance it will be Bournemouth or Brighton. Or maybe Cardf is worth a flutter.The people of Leicester are confused, as well they might be. They don’t know what they’re allowed to do any more. I don’t blame them.But it will be as nothing to the confusion across the country which comes as a result of Super Saturday.July  is the day the Government has said we can shake off our chains and go out and get wrecked. Or something.Have you got any plans for the weekend  Going to a rave  Or just down the pub to breathe over as many people as you possibly can. Here’s my big worry. That Super Saturday will be followed, five days later, by Terrible Thursday.Five days is the average time it takes for the Covid virus to make itself known to the person it has taken up home in. That slightly ticklish cough. Bit of a temperature. Uh-oh.Restaurants, pubs, campsites and children’s playgrounds will all be open for business from Saturday. Oh, and hairdressers. Remember them Obviously, it is right that the UK must emerge from what the Prime Minister called its long hibernation. But I think these things need to be done gradually, rather than all at once.Frankly, I would have started with our schools. Teachers have proved themselves to be just about the only people in the country who can’t work from home. Most kids have enjoyed painfully few virtual lessons, and reopening schools first would have shown where our priorities lie.But it’s not a good idea, in my book, to release the bats all in one go. Many people will have taken from Boris’s announcement last week that, after July , lockdown is effectively over.And some of the Government’s guidelines make it easy to be confused.  The two-metre social-distancing rule has been relaxed to something called “one metre-plus”. I haven’t a clue what dference that makes.And the whole thing is very dficult to monitor. The police say they don’t know how they will deal with it.The virus has been dying out because, by and large, we have been abiding by lockdown. The summer sun has helped, too. The best thing we can do to keep that curve plummeting is to do much as we have been doing so far.The last thing we need this summer is a sudden second spike.If you use that phrase you’re supposedly signalling you’re vulnerable. And need attention. But what about the ones who really did have pasta and liked it  And aren’t at all messed up but just want to share their evening meal experiences in a very real sense  They are strange creatures, the young.THE country is on course for a wonderful, “V-shaped economic recovery”, according to a bloke at the Bank of England.I don’t know what that means. A month or so back, the Bank of England was saying the economy was in ruins for ever, mass unemployment, bankruptcies – giant mutant crabs marching across the country eating our children. Or something.Never believe an economist. You’d be better off talking to Mystic Meg.THE latest historical figure to be attacked by people with no sense of history is Charles Dickens.A former Green Party councillor, Ian Driver, sprayed graffiti on a museum to the author, with the inevitable word “racist”.I supposewe were to ban Dickens, it would bring cheer to millions of schoolkids.Great Expectations can be a bit of a grind to get through when you are young.But this tearing down of history has to stop.Was Dickens racist  Yup. He lived in Victorian Britain. Almost everybody had views which wouldn’t go down very well today.But he was also a brilliant writer and a philanthropist.We are all better than our worst acts.The Chinese authorities are reportedly sterilising these people now – taking a leaf out of Hitler’s book. Yet this outrage raises barely a flicker of publicity. Even other Muslim countries don’t complain too much. That’s because they don’t want to upset the third worst country in the world . And what does the United Nations say  Nothing. Just like it says nothing about China’s occupation of Tibet, or its bullying of democracy campaigners in Hong Kong.A GOOD plan from the Prime Minister. Boris wants to turn the deserted shops in our high streets into homes for people.If he did that, he’d cure half of our housing problem very quickly. Without paving over the entire country for new estates.Many of our high streets are decaying. People now go to out-of-town shopping centres for an afternoon of misery with the missus.But here’s another idea for BoJo. Offices.Lockdown proved we don’t need offices like we used to. They were invented because we needed places to shuffle paper around. But we don’t use paper any more. And during lockdown people worked perfectly well from home.Imagine how many homes we could create by changing offices into flats.And how much rent businesses would save.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The dramatic arrest of his friend Ghislaine Maxwell and her public ­evisceration by US investigators has increased the pressure on him tenfold.This will not go away. title: norman baker prince andrew royal title
story: He may be holed up in his sprawling residence in Windsor Great Park, fearful even to pop out for a takeaway from his favourite Pizza Express branch in Woking, but the net is slowly closing in on Randy Andy.He hadn’t really invited paedophile Jeffrey Epstein up to Sandringham for a “straightforward shooting weekend”, he told the BBC in his car-crash interview last year.He had invited his old friend Ghislaine Maxwell, and she happened to bring Epstein along. That now looks like a very unfortunate explanation. He has straightforwardly shot himself in the foot.It was Maxwell who introduced Andrew to Epstein. It was Maxwell who was Andrew’s guest at Buckingham Palace last summer. And it was Maxwell whose house was the venue for the infamous photo of Andrew with his arm round the bare midrf of young Virginia Roberts who says she was a sex slave for Epstein and a bit of flesh to service his important friends.Andrew told the BBC he went all the way to New York to break off his friendship with Epstein, by then a convicted paedophile. And then stayed for four days at his swanky Manhattan house where he was given a dinner in his honour.Oh, and shortly afterwards Epstein handed over £, as his contribution to the Help The Fergie Fund. It’s a very odd way to end a friendship.Epstein may have died in prison – no doubt very conveniently for lots of famous and powerful people – but it has not stopped the calls for prosecutions of those connected with Epstein, and the calls for justice from Epstein’s victims.The FBI have made it plain they want to talk to Andrew. But he seems determined to keep as far as possible away from them.Geoffrey Berman, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, told reporters earlier this year that Andrew had so far given zero co-operation.Lisa Bloom, representing the women who say they were abused by Epstein, called Andrew’s refusal to answer questions ‘a slap in the face’ for the women.Yet the pariah prince was at it again yesterday, insisting he has in fact offered to co-operate.Well there is a very simple way of finding out who is telling the truth. Let him publish the letters and emails he has sent to the US law enforcement agencies and we can judge for ourselves.Overall, Andrew has done more to undermine the British royal family than any other living person. He is the gt that just keeps on giving for those who want to replace the monarchy with a republic.When local councils earlier this year were told to fly the flag for his birthday there was uproar. The Sun captured it perfectly in its front page headline: Union Joke.Meanwhile a Yougov poll revealed that only  in  have a favourable opinion of him. The only surprise is that it was that high.Horrendous as all the Epstein and Maxwell stuff is, that is just one item in the charge sheet against Andrew.There is the calamitous way he damaged Britain’s image abroad over many years as our trade envoy as he went round the globe insulting those he came into contact with and belting out his saloon bar views, views very often the exact opposite of agreed government policy.Diplomats called him His Buffoon Highness for his mixture of arrogance, rudeness, ignorance and stupidity.There is his outrageous use of helicopters, often to get to golf courses, and private jets when commercial flights would do - all charged to the taxpayer.There is all the dodgy company in dodgy countries he has kept – nasty dictators, outright crooks, alleged torturers, even a convicted gunrunner - some of whom he has accepted gts from, and some he even weaselled into Buckingham Palace, so tainting the Queen with his dubious associates.There is the wealth he has amassed from questionable sources, whether through shady offshore companies, using a  name, Andrew Inverness, or direct from his dodgy friends.What a stroke of luck that he was able to offload his old house, Sunninghill Park, which had been on the market for years at £ million, to Timur Kulibayev, the billionaire son-in-law of the Kazakh dictator, for £ million.Mr Kulibayev never moved in, the house sat empty for a further nine years before being demolished. Why would he pay well over the asking price for a house he never intended to live in And how astonishing on a grant from his mum of £, each year and a tiny naval pension of £,, he has been able to spend £.m refurbishing the property in Windsor Great Park AND get hold of a £m ski chalet in Switzerland.Then there is the appalling boorish behaviour to his protection staff. On at least one occasion he threw stuff on the ground and told them to “f---ing pick that up.”Or there is the casual racism, using phrases like “n----- in the woodpile” which he denies though plenty heard it, or making a jaw-dropping and hugely tasteless joke about camels at a state banquet for the Saudi royals. How to win friends and influence people!Even Donald Trump, who has played golf with Andrew, met him many times, and once lent him a plane, now say:s “I don’t know Prince Andrew.”We’ve all had enough of the obnoxious prince. He is a national embarrassment. When Princess Diana orced from Charles, she was immediately stripped of her HRH status yet the Prince of Sleaze keeps his. He should have his taken away without any further delay. Let him be Andrew Inverness, since he likes that name.The victims of Epstein will be scarred for le. If he has a scrap of decency left inside him, he will travel to the United States and tell the FBI all he knows.This is one trip for Air Miles Andy that the taxpayer would be prepared to pay for - especiallyit is a one-way ticket.       Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris local lockdown
story: The Prime Minister today warned the Government would be forced to step inpeople did not behave as pubs reopen tomorrow.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSpeaking at a Downing Street press conference, Boris threatened to hit the nation with local lockdowns.He said: Just as when we first locked down, we will only succeed in reopeningeveryone works together. Because we are not out of the woods yet. The virus is still with us and the spike in Leicester has shown that. If it starts running out of control again the Government will not hesitate in putting on the brakes and re-imposing restrictions.That could mean shutting business venues, closing schools or urging people to stay at home.This is a big turning point for us. Weve got to get it right.Boris explained the Governments approach would now use five components going forward.These are: The PM vowed to make the most of the easing of restrictions, but warned the public to enjoy summer safely.He added: I will certainly buy and drink a pint, but not a yard”.Boris also warned local lockdowns will now be a feature of our lives for some time to come, butcarefully calibrated on the scientic circumstances.He added: We need to move away from blanket measures to local targeted measures.With each local outbreak we see what works well, to learn better for next time.The PM also did not rule out another national lockdown in the event of a second wave.His comments came as the Chief Scientic Adviser Sir Patrick Vallance warned more outbreaks were inevitable.He said: “There will be an increase in local outbreaks, theres no question about that.“Winter is the big risk. Its been suppressed and we need to keep it suppressed for a more covid-safe world.Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty added that the possibility of a second wave will stay with us for a very long time .He added: If iniduals, families and firms do not take them seriously the possibility of a second wave goes up sharply.”Earlier this week the PM warned the public that they must do their bit to stay safe ahead of pubs and restaurants opening again at the weekend.In an interview he said: “Do not undo the sacrices you have made with reckless behaviour.We do not want to see businesses have to close again.The Government insisted the whole nation - or just parts of it - could be locked down againcases spike once again.The British Beer  Pub Association, UKHospitality, the London Night Czar and the National Police Chiefs Council urged people to support landlords and others as pubs open their doors for the first time in months.The Campaign for Real Alealso issued guidance to people planning to have a pint in England tomorrow.Camra said people should order and be served at their table, give details of their name and a phone number to help with contact tracing, and might not be allowed to shelter insideit rains.This week Leicester became the first city to have restrictions reimposed after a rise in cases.Some of the other rules included to keep people safe from Saturday will include:Police fear that the opening up of huge parts of the economy will cause chaos at the weekend.They are preparing for a New Years Eve situation with increased violence, clashes with police and anti-social behaviour.Scotlands First Minister Nicola Sturgeon urged Scots not to dash across the border to get a pint in England - title: pubs open 6am saturday
story: Tomorrow is Super Saturday, meaning Brits can finally sit in their local and order a pint three months after they were ordered to temporarily close amid the coronavirus crisis.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesRestaurants and cafes are also allowed to start serving customers again and not just for takeaways.The Government said that most ofthe new rules and regulations would be in place just after midnight. But pubs wouldnt be allowed to reopen until am - just in case anyone wanted to try and get a late-night pint in.However, it will depend on the licence that each pub has as to when they can actually serve you a drink.The PMs spokesperson said this lunchtime the change was a sensible precaution just to stress that pubs shouldn’t open at midnight. The reopen date should be in the daytime on July th. Today Rishi Sunak helped pubs prepare on a visit to the The Bell  Crown pub in Chiswick. The Chancellor helped move some barrels and prepared cutlery.JD Wetherspoon will be opening its pubs at am tomorrow.It will reopen  pubs on July  after Boris Johnson gave the green light, but you unlike other boozers you cant currently book tables in advance.Weve also reported on a new map showing you which beer gardens will be open this weekend.Pubs have been kitted out with screens, posters and floor markings to help keep customers safe.But Greene King pubs are not to due toand welcome customers until Monday - to give landlords and managers enough time to make sure branches are Pubsafe - or Covid- secure.A spokesperson for the chain said: We have decided to open our managed pubs from Monday July  so we can open as many as possible with our Pubsafe promises in place for the safety of our customers and team members.We look forward to welcoming back customers to our pubs and providing that great hospitable pub experience we all love.Some police forces - including Devon and Cornwall - have said punters would have a two-hour limit on staying in any establishment.Chief Constable Sawyer said today: Our licensed and hospitality industry will re-open on Saturday, but it will be a very dferent experience for those going to a pub or restaurant.I strongly encourage you to book your visit and you will be restricted to two hours in an establishment. We want people to enjoy that experience, but we cannot tolerate scenes like we have witnessed in Exmouth and on Plymouth’s Barbican in the last week.However, No stressed this would not be a rule implemented across the country, and it would be down to dferent forces to implement their own rules.A spokesperson said it was not part of the regulations… pubs and restaurants in particular do sometimes put time-limits you can have a table for.But going back the local on Saturday wont be the same as it was before.Instead youll have to stick to tough new rules to keep everyone safe during the coronavirus pandemic.People will have to book ahead, and in some places order via an app.Table service will be required, and in many pubs you wont be allowed to order at the bar.In larger pubs, the tables will need to be rearranged so that they sit at least a metre away from the next one.It means boozers will only be operating around  per cent capacity, so customers will also be encouraged to book a table before arriving at their local.People will only be allowed to go out to the pub with one other household at a time.And the lead member will have to leave their contact details with the pub just in case theres an outbreak, or they end up near someone who later tests positive for the virus.Those details will be destroyed by the pubs after  days.The Sun revealed this week that pubs will be allowed to show the football - but it will have to be on quietly.Anything that encourages people to raise their voice shouldnt be allowed.This is because of the potential to spread the virus through droplets in the air.People in Scotland will have to wait a little longer before they can enjoy a cold pint at their pub - as beer gardens arent meant to open until July .Indoor restaurants and pubs can open their doors from July , too.However, many pubs are not going to open up their doors at all on Saturday - for fears they cant keep people safe.Some landlords fear they cannot enforce Covid- social distancing rules when partying punters flood in for their first pint since March. Sunderland bars including Ttonic, Chaplins, The Point, Glitter Ball and Arizona will remain shut.Ian High, operations and finance director of Pub Culture, which runs venues in the North East including the Dun Cow in Sunderland, told the Sunderland Echo: The health and safety of our staff and customers is our top priority.We are working through the guidelines provided for the hospitality industry and want to make sure that when we open, we are providing the safest possible environment.Leading doctors, police and campaigners urged revellers to drink responsibly to avoid ending up injured and in under pressure hospitals.Some even fear that emergency departments could see as many drunk patients as New Years Eve.  To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen anxious epstein maxwell andrew
story: Ghislaine Maxwells arrest yesterday has caused fresh and imminent concerns for the Royal Family, following accusations of Andrew hiding behind them to conceal his alleged part in the Jeffrey Epstein saga.Jeffrey Epsteins former girlfriend Maxwell was once a welcome visitor at royal homes, would stay overnight at Sandringham, and would be invited to parties at Windsor Palace.Now, having been arrested on child sex charges, the Palace fears Maxwell will damn Prince Andrew and do further damage to the Royals reputation.One lawyer who represents some of Epsteins victims has called on the Duke of York to come forward and speak to US prosecutors about his friendship with the financier.Spencer Coogan told BBC Radio s Today programme: I certainly think Prince Andrew has a story to tell. On behalf of the victims we have continuously asked him to step forward, step up, be a man and tell us what he knows.He has been hiding behind not only the royal family but his attorneys.Regardless of his position we, on behalf of the victims, hope that he will step forward and speak up about what he witnessed, at the very least when he was visiting themansion in New York, when he visited the home in Palm Beach and when we know he was down visiting the Virgin Islands mansion.Andrews friendship with Ghislaine did not fade, despite Epsteins charges last summer.He secretly met Maxwell at Buckingham Palace on June  last year - a fortnight after US prosecutors said they would be reopening their inquiry into Epstein. Maxwell was in London for the Cash and Rocket rally for  of the worlds most successful women, and was pictured before a photocall at Wellington Arch.The British socialite has also previously been photographed at Prince Andrews side in the Royal Enclosure at Ascot, where admission is at Her Majestys discretion.Andrew failed to sever contacts with Epstein after he was first accused of under-age sex offences - causing many to wonder why.He ended up cutting ties with Epstein — but only after he was photographed walking with the financier in Central Park, New York.Maxwells arrest, with her knowledge of the alleged activities of the paedophile financer, must have been unnerving for the Royal Family, who are aware of Andrews close friendship with her.What Maxwell may reveal may have the potential to drag the good name of the Royal Family through the mud once again.Prince Andrews relations with Epstein and Maxwell has been causing concern and chaos for the last seven months - as revelations lap closer and closer to Buckingham Palace.Ever since his Newsnight interview where Andrew failed to offer any sympathy for Epstein’s victims and showed no remorse over his friendship with the billionaire sex offender, fears about the implications for the Prince have multiplied.In the prominent photo of Prince Andrew, standing with his arm around teenager Virginia Roberts who alleges her and the Price had sex three times, Maxwell is standing in the background.Her arrest now may lead to more information on what supposedly went on - especially considering it was Maxwell who first introduced Andrew to the disgraced financier.As the Royal Family and their advisers have agonised over how best to protect the integrity of the monarchy from the fall-out of the Epstein affair, there may be some slim consolation.The charges brought by the FBI against Maxwell relate to a period in the mid-s — before Prince Andrew had ever met Epstein.The decision to strip Andrew of all royal duties and force him to step down from official engagements also, in hindsight, was a good move.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe biggest changes since England plunged into lockdown three months ago will kick in this Saturday. Pubs, hairdressers, hotels, campsites, restaurants, cinemas, museums and galleries can all open on July  in England. There are also changes to gatherings and the two-metre rule, allowing you to becloser to those you love. Then on July , thereaposll be big changes to quarantine for people wanting to go on holiday - plus, aposshieldingapos people can hug and kiss relatives for the first time. But nightclubs, gyms, swimming pools, nail and tanning salons, tattoo studios and bowling alleys stay shut. All the venues allowed to open will look dferent to before - with screens, social distancing and booking systems. But so-called aposSuper Saturdayapos - held appropriately on US aposIndependence Dayapos - will still see far more venues open at once than many people thought would ever happen. And Downing Street has refused to say whether itaposs expecting the changes to push the crucial aposRapos rate of infection above one. That has triggered fears that debauched scenes in pubs and bars could trigger new outbreaks of the virus.  The government has already had to enforce a local lockdown in Leicester, where the below measures wonapost happen - and schools and non-essential shops have shut. Boris Johnson has urged people to stick to the rules and not turn into a roiling, bacchanalian mass. So what can you do from July , evenyou donapost want to  And what is still off the table  Hereaposs a complete guide for England. Please note Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland all have separate rules. Things you can do already  Non-essential shops, schoolsand other premises like car showrooms and outdoor markets have already reopened in England. People are now allowed to gather in groups of up to six outdoors in a park or garden, with social distancing. The .million most vulnerable people, who are aposshieldingapos, have been allowed to go outside alone or with one other personfor walks. And people can form a support bubble, joining two households together permanently to hug, kiss, stay the night and share childcare. However, indoor gatherings of two or more people not in the same household or bubble are still banned. And people are still banned from staying overnight away from where they live. From July , much of those laws are being abolished in England and replaced with guidance. Things you can do from July  Venues that CAN reopen in England from July  All these venues can reopen in England providing they can show they are aposCovid-secureapos:Hotels and BBs Holiday apartments or homes Cottages or bungalows Campsites Caravan parks Boarding houses Places of worship Libraries Community centres Restaurants, cafes and workplace canteens Bars Pubs Cinemas Bingo halls Theatres and concert halls - but on the basis it’s not a live performance. They can only screen past performances for example Museums and galleries Hair salons and barbers Outdoor playgrounds Outdoor gyms Funfairs Theme parks Adventure parks and activities Amusement arcades Other indoor leisure centres and facilities - including indoor gaming, social clubs, model villages, and indoor attractions at aquariums and zoos.You can visit friends and family indoors - but you canapost hug  People in England can have people round their house, including to stay overnight from July  - but they can’t hug. For the first time since March, indoor gatherings will be allowed between two households who havenapost joined together in a “bubble”. This applies to all indoor gatherings, be they in private homes or in places like pubs . When you are indoors, your household will be able to meet with one other household at a time. There is no limit on the size of either of the households which can meet. And unlike with bubbles, ’exclusivity’ is not required. So you can have one friend round for a meal one weekend and another friend round another weekend. But dferent households should continue to remain socially distant from one another when they meet. That means following the m or ‘m plus’guidance, and also following other advice such as regular hand washing. You can meet more people outdoors  There is a slight change to the rules for people meeting outdoors from July . Currently up to six people from up to six households can meet in a park or garden,they maintain social distancing. This limit will continue, but it will change from a legal restriction to guidance, plus there will also now be another option. Two households of any size - for example, two families of four - can now also meet outdoors, as long as they maintain social distancing. So you can either meet five friends from dferent households, or an unlimited number from one household. The two-metre rule is changing  The -metre social distancing rule in England is changing from July . Where it’s not possible to stay  metres apart, people are instead advised to keep to a distance of “one metre plus”. This means staying one metre apart - plus mitigations which reduce the risk of transmission. On public transport, it means people stay one metre away but with a face covering. In other spaces it will likely mean having screens between tables, making sure people face away from each other, putting in hand washing facilities, minimising amount of time spent with people from dferent households., and being outdoors where possible. Government officials say mitigations at one metre have a “broadly equivalent impact” as staying two metres apart. But the risk of catching the virus from someone is still much higheryouaposre one metre away from them, compared to two metres away. If you can stay m apart, you should.  Pubs, bars, restaurants, cafes and workplace canteens can all reopen in England from July  - both indoor and outdoors. But thereaposs a catch -youaposre indoors, you can only meet with people from one other household. And you should still maintain social distancing rules. That means staying either two metres apart, or one metre apart with mitigationyou canapost manage two metres. Loud music, dance floors, propping up the bar or standing in groups are all banned, and pubs will be encouraged to have table service where possible. All venues are expected to keep a record of people who visit, to enable contact tracing. But landlords aren’t expected to police which household customers belong to, or check ID of everyone coming in. Hairdressers and barbers are allowed to reopen in England from July  with protective measures - including face visors for those cutting hair. Millions of Brits can finally get a haircut after more than three months of having their locks chopped at home. But they will be appointment-only, use disposable gowns and in many cases use a one-in, one-out system. Nail salons, which involve people sitting face to face, will remain shut for the foreseeable. And eyelash extensions are largely ruled out because of the amount of face-to-face contact. You can go on staycation - but not to hostels  Hotels, BBs, holiday apartments or homes, cottages or bungalows, campsites, caravan parks and boarding houses can all reopen to paying guests in England from July . Again, they must follow Covid-secure guidelines - but people will be able to stay overnight away from their home. Despite concerns over shared facilities, campsites will be able to reopen in England from July . This includes showers and washing-up blocks. But hostels with shared bedrooms cannot yet. This is dferent to Wales which is keeping both campsites and hostels shut. You can get married - but not have a proper reception  Church services - including weddings - are allowed from July theyaposre done in a socially-distanced way. But only up to  people can attend including the couple, officiants, guests, photographers, security and caterers. And limits still apply on indoor gatherings, meaning there wonapost really be a chance to have a reception. Ceremonies should be concluded in the shortest reasonable time and hands should be washed before and after and the rings are exchanged. Brides can be walked down the aisle - but not arm-in-arm, unless the escort lives in the same household. Books, service sheets and prayer mats should be removed - with single-use alternatives provided as long as they are removed by the person attending the wedding.  You can go to church - but not sing Places of worship reopen in England from July , as above. But not full singing services, due to the risk of spreading the virus. You can visit cinemas, galleries and museums  Saturday  July is the date cinemas, galleries and museums can reopen in England. Guidance includes one-way systems, spaced queuing, increased ventilation, and pre-booked tickets. A No source said: We are only able to move forward this week because the vast majority of people have taken steps to control the virus. But the more we open up, the more important it is that everyone follows the social distancing guidelines. We will not hesitate to reverse these stepsit is necessary to stop the virus running out of control. Things you can do from July  Shielded people can meet groups of friends outside  Shielding will be eased for .million vulnerable people in Englandfrom Monday July . They can go out and meet up to five friends - andthey live alone, form a aposbubbleapos with another household. From August , the advice to shield ends completely. But Statutory Sick Pay and direct food parcels for the shielding will also end on August , prompting alarm. Thereaposs also anger at the failure to have a legal safeguard against people being forced back to work. What about travel  Can I go on holiday  From Saturday, the Foreign Officeaposs warning against all but essential international travel will be lted for some countries.And from  July, people ing to England from certain countries will not need to self-isolate. The countries that England has exempted from the quarantine rule are here At the time of publishing th UK government has not published the list of colour coded countries setting out the risk of travelling to certain countries.  Things you still canapost do from July  Venues that CANaposT reopen in England from July  These venues are still banned from reopening and have no confirmed date:Nightclubs Bowling alleys and skating rinks Indoor play areas including soft play Spas Nail bars Beauty salons Swimming pools Tattoo and piercing studios Massage parlours Water parks Indoor fitness and dance studios Gyms Conference centres, other than for people who already work there.You canapost go to the gym  Government sources said gyms remain shut because there is a “far greater risk of infection” due to people breathing harder and touching surfaces. That outraged the gym industry, which demanded a date. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden later insisted: Subject to public health, our aspiration is to reopen gyms  leisure facilities in mid-July. You canapost send your child to school  Only years R,  and  are allowed back to primary schools in England at the moment. The government wants all children back in September - but was forced to drop plans to do it earlier.  You canapost see a live theatre show Theatres and concert halls can reopen in England from July  - but onlyit’s not a live performance. Instead theatres and concert halls can screen past performances. Government sources said theatres have an issue with ensuring the actors themselves can move around the stage in a safe way.

After months of waiting and craving, weaposre just hours away from finally being able to enjoy a cold pint in the pub. People in England canapost wait to get back into their favourite boozer on Saturday, and bargain chain JD D Wetherspoon is preparing for a busy weekend. Staff at the Mossy Well in Muswell Hill will open its doors two hours before theyaposre allowed to sell alcohol, and theyaposre expecting to have people queuing outside. However there are going to be some big changes in the pub to ensure customers and staff can follow social-distancing rules safely . When the Mossy Well is full it can hold  people but that figure will be considerably less under the new tables-only set up.  And when thereaposs no more room, a one-in one-out queue will be operated at the door by a member of staff with a counter. As for who enforces social distancing rules inside, Wetherspoons is placing faith in their loyal customers to adhere to the rules and drink responsibly.
