title: six-new-things-can-today-scotlands-lockdown-eased
story: The First Minister last week confirmed an acceleration of easing restrictions across the country following a continued suppression of the virus.But Nicola Sturgeonhas since urged the public not to ldquosquander that progress as we move into more freedom.Here, we detail out the six changes taking place today:Shopping and outdoor marketsOne of the most anticipated announcements from lockdown, non-essential shopsare now officially allowed to reopen.The one restriction still in place, however, is these must be street-access retail. Non-essential stores within shopping centres malls must remain closed until Phase .Commenting on the re-opening this morning, the First Minister tweeted: ldquoIf you plan on visiting shops today, please do so responsibly.ldquoMaintain physical distancing, follow hygiene advice, wear a face covering and respect staff who may be asking you to shop dferently.ldquoWersquove made so much progress against the virus ndash letrsquos not squander it. #StaySafe.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.On Friday, First Minister @NicolaSturgeon set out guidance on how to #StaySafe when some shops reopen today following changes to #coronavirus measures.Find out more ## https:t.co DwqbXAFMk pic VVuUhPzZWorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .This does NOT include indoor workspaces that are due to open in Phase  ndash like non-essential offices and call-centres.Moving homeFrom today, all home moves are permitted, provided they can be carried out safely.This includes students moving home and other home moves resulting in two households merging.It also applies to custom and self-builders looking to acquire a plot or a property to renovate or to demolish.The Scottish Government has issued guidance around this ndash as well as encouraging people to take part in virtual property viewings as much as possible with further guidance around health and safety here.Outdoor sports courts and playgroundsFrom today, outdoor sports courts can reopen to the public.This includes courts for tennis, basketball, volleyball , Multi-Use Games Areasand netball.Participants must maintain strict physical distancing at all times when using outdoor sports courts. This does not include pitches used for contact sports.Playgrounds can also reopen.These were closed at the start of lockdown amid fears the virus could spread through the physical contact in these areas.Marriages and civil partnershipsMarriages and civil partnerships can resume from today.These have to have a minimal number of attendees and, despite the Scottish weather, be outdoors only.All the participants, including the couple and the witnesses, must come from no more than three households and will be possible up to amaximum of eight.The celebrant or registrar will not count as one of the households.Zoos and garden attractionsMust to the anticipation of those in Edinburgh, zoos and garden attractions can open from today.However the Scottish Government guidance says these are initially for local access only ndash meaning people broadly within five miles can attend.Increased hygiene measures are encouraged, with pre-booking tickets online also advised.

story: First came queues of cars as McDonalds opened its drive-throughs, and now people rushed to the high streets as retailers were allowed to reopen their doors.In Glasgow, queues for the Argyle Street and Sauchiehall Street Primark snaked around the city centre from the early hours of the morning despite the pouring rain.Primark in Argyle Street, GlasgowLong lines were also seen at the Princes Street store in Edinburgh and Union Street branch in Aberdeen as enthusiastic shoppers ed to stores for the first time in months.Retailers were officially allowed to reopen this morning as part of further easing of lockdown restrictions during phase two of the Governments plans.But the enthusiasm of some shoppers left people ided.Shops finally opened again today in Scotland and honestly I am SO HAPPY that Irsquoll finally be able to buy smaller clothes that fit me ## yes Irsquoll be queuing for primark in the rain at some point this week ###However, while some were willing to withstand rain, others were not completely on board with the idea.I feel sorry for anyone getting soaked in the queue for Primark in town today. #### pic ntfpxJSJqIf you found yourself in a massive queue for Primark this morning then therersquos a % chance yoursquore an absolute zoomerHowever, others slammed the abundance of "snide" comments about the queues.Its easy to write a snide tweet about people queueing for Primark. title: east-lothian-council-shop-local-campaign
story: East Lothian Council has launched a campaign for residents to lsquoStay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothianrsquo by using local shops and businesses.With many businesses hit hard by the Covid- pandemic, retailersacross the county re-opened this week and introduced social distancing measures to keep customers and staff safe.And the council is calling on people to back their local shops and services by using them while following safety advice.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos Provost and spokesperson for economic development and tourism, said: ldquoEast Lothianrsquos shops and local businesses have had to face particularly challenging circumstances over the last few months, but, as our high streets start to open up again, they are keen to welcome existing and new customersldquoIrsquom delighted to support the launch of East Lothian Councilrsquos new campaign ndash Stay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothian.ldquoItrsquos about sending out a message that East Lothian is getting back open for business ndash whatever products or services yoursquore looking for, yoursquore very likely to find them here in East Lothian.ldquoLocal businesses are essential for our economy. They bring growth and innovation, provide employment and support the local economies and communities. They also care about their community.ldquoBy continuing to stay safe and shop locally the people of East Lothian can help local businesses, so integral to the fabric and character of our community, to not only survive but thrive.The campaign comes as East Lothian councillor Craig Hoy, who is the Scottish Conservative candidate for the Holyrood  election, launched a locallsquoSupport Our High Streetsrsquo campaign.Mr Hoy has already called on the council to make it easier for local restaurants, cafes and bars to re-open by allowing them to use public space near their venues to provide al fresco services.He said: ldquoWith East Lothianrsquos shops re-opening, itrsquos vital that we Support Our High Streets, save jobs and help the local economy bounce back.ldquoWe can all do our bit by making sure we shop local and visit our fantastic range of cafes, restaurants and bars as they begin to re-open.

title: east-lothian-council-safe-space-funding
story: The local authority has been given pound.million of Scottish Government funding to allow it to transform its high streets and bring shoppers back.However, the plans have sparked concern among some residents, who questioned whether the council would use the money to introduce long-term changes proposed before lockdown which brought mixed reactions form the public.One person on social media accused them of using a ldquoback door to get what they want.While Haddington councillor Craig Hoy warned that improvements had to be made without creating unnecessary restrictionsHe said: ldquoIt is important that our high streets are capable of allowing pedestrians to be able to socially distance, giving people the confidence to get out and about.ldquoBut, at the same time, itrsquos important we donrsquot impose unnecessary restrictions or reduce parking provision in a way which is detrimental to trade.ldquoWe need to strike a careful balance here and ensure the interventions are proportionate.The local authority launched its bid for funds from the Spaces for People Fund last month with a public consultation online.It drew just under , responses, with  detailed comments about improvements for town centres and roads.Although the funding is for temporary measures, the online questionnaire asked those taking partthey would support changes ldquolong term.Many people who took part in the survey called for pavements to be widened and speed reductions on some streets, as well as improved cycle lanes and footpaths.The council initially said it was applying for pound, from the Spaces for People Fund but has revealed it received nearly four times the original amount.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute council leader and environment spokesperson, said: ldquoThe pound.m funding will enable East Lothian Council to introduce a number of temporary measures to our streets as further easing of lockdown restrictions are applied.ldquoMany local shops are re-opening for business and these temporary changes are focused on protecting public health by providing necessary space for continued observance of physical distancing whilst supporting businesses and their customers.ldquoWhilst planning these new temporary changes, we have taken into account the erse needs of local communities to ensure as much as possible that those with mobility or sight concerns will be as supported as able-bodied iniduals.ldquoThese measures will create space for everyone, whether on foot, bike, wheelchair or using prams and buggies, and will support the initial stages of local economic recovery.The council said detailed plans of the changes to be introduced were still being discussed and no maps or additional information were currently available.However, it said a staged approach would be taken, with measures to be introduced including temporary widening of some footways, mph speed limits, some segregated space for cycling and opportunities for businesses to use pavement space for customer queuing.Some parking spaces within town centres may be temporarily removed.

story: One of only eight to occur this decade, all eyes will be on the skies early on Sunday morning.Here, we bring you everything you need to know ahead of the penumbral lunar eclipse.A penumbral lunar eclipse takes place when the moon moves through the faint, outer part of earths shadow.A lunar eclipse happens when the Earth comes between the sun and the moon, therefore blocking some or all of the sunrsquos light from reaching the moon.Therefore, the moon cannot shine ndash because its surface is not reflecting the sunrsquos rays.The eclipse will be visible over ScotlandAccording to TimeAndDate, a penumbral lunar eclipse occurs when the sun, earth and moon are imperfectly aligned.When this happens, the earth blocks some of the sunrsquos light from directly reaching the moonrsquos surface, and covers all or part of the moon with the other part of its shadow.People in Scotland are urged to find an unobstructed area with a free sight to the southwest for a best view of the title: boxing-fan-floored-birthday-wish-world-champion-josh-taylor
story: Mckenzie Kearsley-Edmond celebrated turning  on June  and received a signed picture of Josh Taylor in action.However, it was a present he could not unwrap that really floored the youngster.Taylor, , took time out from his training regime to film a short video wishing Mckenzie, who hopes to follow in the boxerrsquos footsteps and join Lochend Amateur Boxing Club, a happy birthday.His dad Chris Kearsley, who lives in Dunbar, said: ldquoIrsquove never seen him so emotional in my le. He was just about in tears of happiness.The incredible gt came about through Chris, who is a self-employed joiner, getting in touch with Jenner Charlton.The Duns-based photographer has been a regular at Taylorrsquos fights and was able to not only arrange for a signed picture of the boxer in action against Ryan Martin but also line up the birthday message.Taylor, from Prestonpans but now living in Haddington, said: ldquoHi Mckenzie, hi wee man, happy birthday.ldquoHope you have a great day and Irsquoll see you at Lochend [Amateur Boxing Club] one day when it opens back up.ldquoWersquoll do a bit of training together.Mckenzie, who is going into P at Dunbar Primary School, has been clocking up the miles watching ldquohis hero.He has taken in fights in Glasgow and even met Taylor in unusual circumstances before the county fighter lted the IBF World Super Lightweight title against Ivan Baranchyk.His dad said: ldquoWe were staying at the Radisson RED in Glasgow and got into the lt on the seventh floor.ldquoThe lt stopped on the sixth floor and Shane and Barry McGuigan and Josh all got in and we got a picture with them.Mckenzie and his dad even travelled to London in October to see Taylor put his newly claimed world title up against Regis Prograis and his WBA World Super Lightweight championship.Chris said: ldquoIrsquove always been a boxing fan and kept up training for the last wee while.ldquoWe started following Josh and found out he was from Prestonpans.ldquoWe went to watch his fight with Viktor Postol in Glasgow, and Lynne Wilson [an ASN auxiliary at Dunbar Primary School] is Joshrsquos cousin.ldquoWe started going to Joshrsquos fights and Mckenzie became interested in boxing.ldquoHe joined the Bronx Boxing Gym in Tranent and was doing a bit of training there.ldquoWe went to all the World Boxing Super Series fights and went to the final in London against Regis Prograis.ldquoMckenzie was on cloud nine for a week afterwards it was a great atmosphere!

title: visitors-given-green-light-return-eskgreen
story: The facility ndash on Shorthope Street near the River Esk ndash closed in mid-March and escaped the deadly virus. Run by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership , the  residents, aged between  and , have been keeping ldquoin good heart during the lockdown.An ELHSCP spokesperson confirmed: ldquoNo one has contracted Covid- at Eskgreen.Now, in line with Scottish Governmentguidance, the residents are looking forward to meeting visitors in outdoor areas only on Wednesdays and Saturdays, -.am and -pm, and Sundays, -pm and -.pm.At the moment, visits are restricted to one lsquokey visitorrsquo and will be held in outdoor areas.Clair Anderson, manager, said: ldquoItrsquos been hard because obviously people are missing their families and friends, but we all know why it has to be this way and we decided to make the best we could of it.ELHSCP introduced very restricted visiting to its four care homes, including Eskgreen, in mid-March, swtly followed by no visiting from March .Clair said: ldquoWe had to act very quickly but I think residents and families understood why and were behind us.ldquoWe managed to get our hands on Kindles and iPads very quickly and helped residents to Skype and FaceTime family and friends. This has really helped to keep people in touch regularly and relieve familiesrsquo anxieties.ldquoWe have a brilliant team spirit in Eskgreen. Relatives and staff have pulled together throughout the outbreak and have concentrated on trying to get as much out of le as possible, even though we were all living through a very challenging time.ldquoWe have kept ourselves really busy and really positive. I think the key to it is trying to get as much fun out of le as you can. So, we have had skittles evenings, birthday parties, Easter celebrations and we pulled out all the stops for VE Day ndash we even had a piper playing in the grounds.ldquoWersquove also had wonderful support from community groups, who have sent gts for us ndash residents and staff! Itrsquos brilliant to have such tangible proof that everyone is thinking of us.ldquoWersquove focused on being active and creative ndash we sing, we dance, we even made a video ndash Somewhere Over the Rainbow ndash which went viral locally."You can see it at bit.ly CZizla and it features residents singing The Wizard of Oz classic and is guaranteed to bring a tear to the eye.ldquoItrsquos also about helping people feel good about themselves so wersquove done a lot of pampering sessions ndash we all have lovely hair and great nails.ldquoWersquove had great help from ELHSCPrsquos care home team too. Theyrsquore a nurse-led team that have been working in care homes across East Lothian for the last four years.ldquoIn addition to their routine work of looking after the clinical needs of residents, like medication and wound care, they also really stepped up to help us during Covid.ldquoThey made sure that all the care homes they work with were on top of the guidance, which was being updated all the time, had access to all the PPE they needed and knew how and when to use it.ldquoI think all care homes in East Lothian, ELHSCP and private, have been doing their very best to keep people cheerful and safe.ldquoAt Eskgreen, I would have to say that we have great support from families, a great staff team and, most of all, great residents. Thatrsquos the secret of our success.Irene Tait, chair of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, said: ldquoWe were delighted and heartened at the way the management and staff of Eskgreen have coped with the coronavirus.ldquoThrough their diligence and great care, they have kept the residents and staff safe from contracting the virus.ldquoWe are all aware of the huge debt of thanks we owe to everyone working in our health and care sector however, itrsquos especially nice to hear good news in our own town and we can be very proud of them.ldquoI would also like to thank everyone who has rallied round to help neighbours, family and strangers at this time ndash it all matters.

title: impressive-floral-display-thank-key-workers
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos Dunbar amenity service team planted the colourful display outside the townrsquos fashion school on Belhaven Road.The design was created by James Scott , assisted by Kenny Aitken, Jamie Smith and trainee Dan Sked.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the town and is the local authorityrsquos spokesman for the environment, told the Courier he was impressed by the work of those involved.He said: ldquoIt is certainly impressive.ldquoIt just shows you the quality of the workmanship we have within our grounds services department, not only in Dunbar but across East Lothian.ldquoThe budget they have to work with is very limited but they do a fantastic job.ldquoAll the plants are grown by our own staff and planted out across the communities across East Lothian.Mr Hampshire described the planting as ldquoa beautul display and an asset to the town.The display uses echeveria elegans for the writing and the main heart contains echeveria Duchess of Nuremberg, pyrethrum, sedum pachyclados, senecio serpens, lobelia and petunia.The surrounding hearts are a mixture of echeverias, sedum, senecio, saxrage, alyssum, petunia, begonia, lobelia and pyrethrum.

title: star-peppa-pig-delights-children-hub-message
story: Daddy Pig sent the children and staff at The Hub at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, Tranent,best wishes as he urged youngsters to ldquobe kind to people.The greeting, which was shared on Twitter, was recorded by actor Richard Ridings, who voices Daddy Pig in the popular cartoon series.In the -second-long message, he sent special greetings to all the children who attended The Hub and their teachers and staff.He told them: ldquoI know we are living in a very, very strange time at the moment but as long as we keep on smiling and keep being kind to people then I think wersquoll all be alright.The message was recorded after Mr Ridings, who played Bernard Green in the BBCrsquos Common As Muck and was also in Alan Ashburnrsquos drama Fat Friends, was approached by the parent of one of the children at the school.And it was shared on Twitter by the school, which admitted depute headteacher Clare Palmer-Fairbairn was ldquoridiculously excited by the message from the Peppa Pig patriarch.Mark McKenzie, who contacted Mr Ridings about the message, said he wanted todo something special for the school.Mark, who lives in Prestonpans with we Laura and their two children, Murray, , and Sophie, seven, is a presenter on BFBS the Forces Station every afternoon and said interviewing lsquoDaddy Pigrsquo Richard last year was a dream for his family.Mark, who has interviewed celebrities from the Bee Gees to David Bowie, said son Murray, who attends The Hub and has a rare chromosome disorder, loved Peppa Pig.He said: ldquoSeeing how Murray responds to the show and his reactions, Peppa Pig has been a regular fixture in our house. When I had the opportunity to interview Richard for BFBS I was excited and nervous ndash he couldnrsquot have been nicer.ldquoWe kept in touch occasionally afterwards he had offered to record a message for my children and I askedhe might share one for the school. He responded straight away.Mark described The Hub, which Murray has been attending since he was three, as ldquoan absolute haven.He said: ldquoThe staff are fantastic and it makes such a dference for us. The integration between the school and Hub is brilliant.Clare Palmer-Fairbairn said: ldquoMark got in touch to say he had a bit of a surprise and, knowing his creative ideas and connections through work, I was intrigued!ldquoMark initially sent the audio clip and I could not believe it was the real deal Daddy Pig! Such a thoughtful and kind gesture from the actor Richard Ridings and for Mark to make this happen.ldquoWe created a bit of suspense prior to the clip being shared, letting the Sandersonrsquos Wynd community know we had a summer message from an international celebrity. There was great excitement and guesses amongst staff as to who it might be!ldquoWhen we shared it in our final week of term, the response was wonderful ndash so many likes and cheerful comments from pupils, staff, parents and carers!ldquoI have been chatting with families over the phone and many spoke about what an amazing surprise this was and how happy it made them.ldquoPart of Daddy Pigrsquos happy message is about smiling, kindness and outdoor learningndash all part of the Sandersonrsquos Wynd approach so we couldnrsquot have asked for a better summer message!

title: pharmacy-owner-retiring-four-decades
story: As he is currently shielding due to the Covid- pandemic, he was sad not to be able to say a fond farewell to his many customers.Eskside Pharmacy has been sold to a new owner and will continue to provide pharmaceutical care for local people.Mr Chetty said: ldquoItrsquos been an immense pleasure to have served the people of Musselburgh and surrounding areas for the last  years. The loyalty and support of the community has been humbling and greatly appreciated.ldquoIrsquom also grateful for the strong working relationships Irsquove had with the surgeries and GPs.ldquoIrsquove been very fortunate to have had such fantastic, hard-working and cheerful staff through all the years and I canrsquot thank them enough for all they have done.ldquoThe current circumstances of Covid- have meant that I havenrsquot been able to say farewells to people in person, which is of great regret. My thoughts will always be with you all and I will still be a regular face up and down High Street.ldquoIrsquom in no doubt the new owners will continue high standards of pharmaceutical care.Mr Chetty, , started at Eskside Pharmacy on High Street in , initially as the manager, before buying the business in .Originally from South Africa, he came to Scotland to study in Edinburgh in the s ndash when apartheid wouldnrsquot allow him to study for the profession in South Africa.As manager of the local pharmacy, he enjoyed the community spirit in Musselburgh and jumped at the chance of establishing and developing the pharmacy.The overriding memory he will take with him is the ldquopositive rapport he has developed with the patients and the people of Musselburgh. He said serving the health and wellbeing of the community had been his number one priority and he always felt that was appreciated by his customers and wider community.He recalled one of his most special memories, when his daughter was in hospital with meningitis and he found out that every church in Musselburgh had said a prayer for her recovery.Just a few months ago, when he was piercing the ears of a girl at the shop, her grandmother told him he had pierced her ears too as well as her daughterrsquos ears, making this the third generation of the same family he had served.He joked that he decided that might be his cue to retire.Mr Chetty, who lives in Longniddry, said Musselburgh had always had a ldquothriving High Street, but it had been challenging to maintain a wide range of businesses to serve the community. He hoped High Street would always remain at the heart of the community.Mr Chetty, who has three children and four grandchildren, one of whom was born just two weeks ago, sadly lost his we Moira two years ago. He said he was ldquovery grateful for the support of the community during her illness and when she passed away.In his retirement, he is looking forward to playing golf, tending his garden and travelling, as well as spending time with his grandchildren. He is also hoping to spend time with family in South Africa.

title: face-coverings-mandatory-scotlands-shops---rules-exempt
story: During her daily briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish Government has been considering the issue of face coverings "for some time now".She confirmed it will become mandatory in Phase .Why the change Face coverings became mandatory in Scotland on all public transport on June .The First Minister said that "as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors.""This is a really important wayfor all of us to help protect each other and to display that sense of solidarity that has served us well," she said.When does it become mandatory Ms Sturgeon said the enforcement will take place on Phase  - July .However sheurged Scots not to wait until next week, asking them to get into the habit now.How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced MsSturgeon also announced that the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.The First Minister also said  patients have now died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from  on Wednesday.A total of , people have tested positive for the virus, up by five from , the previous day.

title: air-bridges-apply-scotland-can-go-holiday-abroad
story: The current -day isolation policy for peopleto or visiting Scotland remains in place for now, the Scottish Government has confirmed, despite the restrictions being eased south of the Border.As title: tv-preview-natalie-dormer-playing-supernatural-demon-penny-dreadful-spin-off
story: The promise of "no makeup" was all it took to sell Rory Kinnear a role in Penny Dreadful: City Of Angels.Show creator John Logan had made the admission in an email subject line, aware that the British actor had previously spoken of his gruelling transition into Frankensteins Creature for the first iteration of the dark fantasy drama, Penny Dreadful.The lure of a simpler guise - in this case a German paediatrician - then, had successfully worked to secure hisfor its much-anticipated spin-off."I knew that something might be up, because Id often mentioned the fact that he made me have a three-and-a-half-hour makeup every day," realised Kinnear, ."So I was already interested - and then he sent me the script. He knew how to whet my appetite."Yet the characters arent the only element getting a makeover: billed as the originals "spiritual descendant", the brand-new -part series will transport viewers from Ripper-era London to the Golden Age of Hollywood in  Los Angeles.A time and place deeply infused with social and political tension, the sequel - which opens with a grisly murder - sees detectives Tiago Vegaand Lewis Michenerbattling the citys rich history. From the building of the first freeways and its traditions of Mexican-American folklore, to the dangerous espionage actions of the Third Reich and the rise of radio evangelism.In amongst the uprising, Kinnear plays Dr Peter Craft, a father of two who flits between caring paediatrician and his turn as head of the German-American Bund, an organisation he hopes will keep the United States isolated from the growing threat of war in Europe."Peter has a lot in common with a lot of characters in the show in that theyre all complex, conflicted, and struggling to do the right thing whilst coming up against temptation," says the star, whos also worked with screenwriter Logan on Bond films Skyfall and Spectre."He has a troubled home le, in that his we is an alcoholic and has seemingly cut herself off from looking after their children," he continues. "And his profession is all about looking after kids, so were expecting that [viewers] sympathise with him."But obviously in meeting Elsa, the path thats in front of him changes, and as a result the audience may have their sympathies change as well."Elsa is just one of a number of guises adopted by Natalie Dormers character, Magda.Dubbed a supernatural demon who can assume the form of anyone she chooses, the Game Of Thrones actress - whose character believes humankind is evil - has her work cut out, as she shts between blonde German housewe Elsa, government assistant Alex, and androgynous freedom fighter Rio.Her goal: to prove her point by nudging the city towards a race war.It was a major endeavour, says the -year-old, "in so far as its a physical and mental exercise because its four characterisations for the price of one"."We realised quite quickly that I had to play them as separate entities becauseyou dont play Elsa and Rio and Alex as fully fleshed out, three-dimensional characters, not only are you doing a disservice to your co-stars, the truth of the entire thing gets completely lost."And that actually, speaking in a pure sense as an actor, in terms of craft, its a joy because it means you have a lot of fun playing with the physicality, with voices, accents, and the costume and hair department..." she notes."I was very pleased to be a stage-trained, classically trained British actor because I really did go right back to my training, in order to do this sort of exercise. It was a nice challenge."Similarly, Kinnear states: "I like playing characters with lots of dferent shades [and] Peter comes upon a fairly invincible force in the shape of Elsa and Magda."But we dont know how much strength he has in him to withstand that temptation," he teases. "You see over the course of the  episodes that he does try, and hes also trying to stand up to the more radical, Nazi wing of the German-American Bund as well, to try and make the claim for peace."Peter is almost the inverse of the Creature, really he is trying desperately to push down his true identity and create someone completely anew. Whereas the Creature was in constant search of his origin and identity.""Magda has this theory that all mankind needs to become the monster he truly is, is to be told that he can, Dormer follows."For me, theres a bit of a premise that good people do bad things, whether its to do with threatening their family, their country or their vulnerability. Its that philosophical question of what it takes to bring out the uglier side in all of us."As for the shows key political themes - take othering, racism, and isions in society, for example - it seems theyre as relevant today as they ever were."What this shows is that all the tensions and dficulties of any large city, which has had a history of oppressing minority groups, have not gone away, and that they will continue to resurfacetheyre not fully addressed or addressed honestly," recognises Kinnear.Can he pinpoint a link between the first iteration and this "I think its that focus on how the supernatural plays out in real peoples lives and the strength of feeling that it can still provoke not only in the s, but today as well," he muses."The first Penny Dreadful was all about the monsters that lie within us and it was using largely pre-existing literary characters," reasons the father of two."This one focuses on that same thing, but also the sense of no matter how much you study and learn, there are things that exist beyond us, beyond our comprehension, which we try to give names to."That can lead to fears, whether irrational or not, but it can also give succour and strength as well."Is there room for another series "John is always several steps ahead," Kinnear finishes. "Not only is he so extraordinarily prolic in terms of all the output that he has, across so many dferent disciplines, he really enjoys it - and Penny Dreadful was his first time doing long-form TV!"There are lots of surprises thrown up in that, but you do have to plan your first three series because thats always the hope!"Watch all episodes of Penny Dreadful: City Of Angels on Sky Atlantic and streaming service NOW TV from Wednesday, July .

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  We   re all public health guinea pigs now    but that   s just the way it has to be
story: Irsquove also started planning a wee holiday up north and have booked a hairdressersrsquo appointment. Irsquove looked out my monthly cinema pass in anticipation of re-opening around July .I appreciate not everyone feels this way, but Irsquom ready to start living again. Irsquom also ready to accept some fundamental political realities.Letrsquos face it, wersquore all just guinea pigs now, part of a radical public health experiment the likes of which has never been attempted before. This experiment is reaching its most dficult phase yet, the bit where the Government has to somehow let people start doing normal things ndash like going back to work and spending money to keep the economy going ndash while simultaneously reminding us that we wersquore not out of the woods yet. They have to encourage people to go out, while keeping them scared.Many ndash including me ndash have criticised politicians for their missteps and mixed messages over the last few months. But I also recognise a number of basic truths that itrsquos better to get onersquos head around sooner rather than later, regardless of party politics.The first is that until coronavirus has been completely eradicated around the world, risk is going to play a part in our lives for the foreseeable future. The second is closely related: the state cannot tell us exactly how to manage this risk in every single circumstance. We may get health advice and government guidance, but ultimately we have to navigate this new, more precarious world on our own.How we do this, and, crucially, how we feel about doing it, depends on many dferent things, of course, not least our age and underlying health, our financial situation and, to a signicant extent, our personality.I know there are some who believe that through lting lockdown restrictions politicians in Westminster and Holyrood are very deliberately handing over responsibility ndash and thus blame ndash to the public for what comes next. And there may be some truth to this. But come on, letrsquos get real.Accusations of ldquomaking it up as they go along are thrown around asthis was an insult rather than simply a fact describing the predicament governments everywhere find themselves in. How could it be otherwise given the extraordinary events of the last six months  And whatrsquos the alternative to us being public health guinea pigs  Staying at home forever Community levels of the virus in Scotland are now low and falling. Our hospitals lie empty. We have a test and trace system in place to ndash hopefully ndash crack down on infections. Meanwhile, wellbeing continues to suffer under the restrictions and hundreds of thousands of jobs hang in the balance. All of these things mean we can and should lt the lockdown. And lting restrictions means the vast majority of folkmust decide for themselves what level of risk they are comfortable contending with, taking into consideration how it might affect their family and community as well as their own personal circumstances.We can help ourselves along the way. Firstly by staying up to date ndash through trusted, legitimate scientic and public information sources ndash about how the virus is transmitted and the best ways to stay safe.We can also resist the temptation to judge others for their decisions. Frankly, Irsquom sick of the army of armchair virologists spouting their culture war vitriol on social media. On one side you have those who seem to relish the lockdown, the class swots who shout too loudly about how they follow every part of the guidanceand seem to revel in the idea of a second wave. On the other side, you have the virus deniers. Both groups peddle fear and misinformation, whether that is their intention or not.At the end of the day none of us, not even the scientists, know whether and when there will be another wave of the virus. Uncertainty permeates through every part of our lives now, and we must find ways to live with and even embrace thiswe are to make it through the tough months ahead. Letrsquos at least try to respect each otherrsquos dferent ways of coping, shall we All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  Why the Border must regain its old role as the country   s first line of defence
story: Yet she is clearly unsettled at the idea of some kind of checkpoint on the A, A, or whichever route she might take. Speculation over testing or quarantining travellers between England and Scotland has been raised as part of a discussion of how to prevent infection from a neighbour with a higher incidence of Covid  than here. As a result, almost overnight the Border has begun to assume a signicance it has not held for centuries.:Thousands back petition to close Scottish border to all but essential trafficThis pandemic might one day be viewed as a textbook illustration of the geopolitical fault lines across the UK. What was once a united front has splintered into four distinct nations, each with a dferent solution to the same problem. Nothing more starkly demonstrates the gulf between the laissez-faire ethos of the Westminsterrsquos panjandrums and the commonsensical attitude at Holyrood than the ways in which they have eased restrictions.The increasingly relaxed English regime appears to be fuelled by wishful thinking rather than science the Scottish situation, meanwhile, is characterised by caution. Long before talk of checkpoints, this was already causing tension. When Englandrsquos routemap out of lockdown was weeks ahead of Scotland, John Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, said those of his constituents close to Borisrsquos bailiwick were confused. Why did one rule apply to their very near neighbours, and another to them The answer seemed obvious ndash it was far too soon to relax ndash but the question vividly demonstrated the nature of this area. Many who live where Hadrianrsquos men boldly marched have a foot in both countries. They might work in one, and live in the other, hail from this side and have relocated to that. They could have family and friends in either camp, who remained out of reach for so long as the Scottish government prohibited meeting.Those Border villagers who defied lockdown to visit a garden centre in Berwick were making a political rather than a horticultural statement. In this, they echoed attitudes since the days of the great reiving clans, who roamed freely on both banks of the Tweed. The Scottish and English kings were so appalled at the regionrsquos lawlessness that, despite being sworn enemies, they worked in tandem to subdue it.Given the way Borderers were treated by their lieges, itrsquos no surprise they thumbed their noses. These days, towns and villages are awash with folk from both sides, thereby creating a unique and strongly bonded region. Little wonder Unionism still pertains hereabouts.:Tourists from England could face -day quarantine in ScotlandCovid- cases flareThat there have been no deaths from Covid  in Scotland for the past few days suggests we are heading in the right direction. But there is a long way still to go. The First Ministerrsquos aim is to eradicate the virus, not merely contain it. Seeing the daily tally of new cases and deaths in England, she seeks confirmation that the Prime Minister has the same objective. But, as she said earlier this week, without such assurances she fears Englandrsquos strategy is ldquoletting it circulate at higher levels as long as it doesnrsquot threaten to overwhelm the NHS.If that is indeed the case, then monitoring passage between the countries is in some respects no dferent from policies implemented by a place like New Zealand. It initially imposed an outright ban on entry, followed later by quarantine on new arrivals. The problem is, as a devolved nation within a union, the consequences of such a step are potentially inflammatory. Some will view it as independence by stealth, a confrontational declaration of autonomy, or simply authoritarianism run rampant. Yet with a summer of staycations approaching, the repercussions of allowing untrammelled travel could be dire.Before the prospect of imposing controls was mooted, people around where I live in Roxburghshire have been scowling at visitors from only a few miles away, let alone the depths of the English shires. When a couple of walkers dared ask a neighbour directions over the hills last week, they narrowly avoided a tirade.The idea of the Border ing to its roots as a frontier inevitably creates a troubling sense of Them and Us, or Friend and Foe. Affront will be taken at any restriction on free transit between south and north. Presumably residents of Scotland who visit England will also be tested or quarantined on their , making it a two-way injunction. Suddenly a weekend break in Northumberland looks a lot less appealing.:YouGov Poll: Half of Conservative voters in England support English independenceYet how exactly would it work  Is it only tourists who will be checked, or will those travelling back and forth for work, be they lorry drivers or business reps, also be subject to testing  Will every road, rail and sea route across the Border from Berwick to Workington be patrolled  Might we see a surge in midnight crossings over no-manrsquos land and rivers, four-by-fours finally justying their existence and canoes retrofitted to ferry families plus their luggage across the Tweed As things stand, there have been no new cases of the virus in the Scottish Borders in two weeks. This beautul, windswept district is starting to feel like a cordon sanitaire, a buffer between the haves and,not precisely the have-nots, then a population beginning slowly but steadily to paralyse the disease.Given our reputation as one of the sickest countries in Europe, we need to take every precaution to protect lives. Reimposing the Border as a barrier and guard would not be popular, and the war-time and military resonances are unsettling. Yet, in light of the high risk of contagion still posed by parts of the south, in the short term it would make sense. If the first thing passengers see as they arrive is not a sig welcoming them to Scotland but an NHS squad, then for the first time since  ndash the last pitched battle between England and Scotland ndash the Border will have regained its old role as the countryrsquos first line of defence.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: agenda-choice-new-cabinet-secretary-important
story: First, Mr Frost as the National Security Adviser. This is a far less serious matter than his becoming Cabinet Secretary. It has few,any, constitutional implications. I worked for a previous incumbent for a couple of years. It is an extremely important role but, as its name suggests, it is primarily advisory ndash and also a kind of personal envoy from the Prime Minister to counterparts overseas. That could be work for a trusted political appointee.:Agenda: Proposed new law could make JK Rowling a criminalIs it a good appointment  That is a more subjective question, and less fundamental. Mr Frostrsquos predecessors have been very senior diplomats, with deep grounding across Britainrsquos foreign policy and security concerns ndash former heads of the Diplomatic Service, Ambassadors in Washington, Paris, Permanent Representatives in Brussels, both to the EU and to Nato. Some have done more than one of these big jobs, in wide, senior international careers.Mr Frost is able and, importantly, has the Prime Ministerrsquos confidence. But his diplomatic career culminated in the important, but not central, ambassadorship to Denmark. He then ran the important, but not central, Scotch Whisky Association, and was special advisor to Mr Johnson, as a Foreign Secretary who earned mixed reviews. Judging Mr Frostrsquos role as chief Brexit negotiator may be premature. But it is odd, after the justied criticism of Sir Mark Sedwillrsquos being both Cabinet Secretary and National Security Adviser, that Mr Frost should have to combine the climax of Brexit negotiations with whatever Middle Eastern politics, for instance, or terrorism, may serve up in the coming months.Choosing the new Cabinet Secretary matters more. Britain wonrsquot acquire a written constitution any time soon. Much therefore depends on working through complex but broadly respected conventions. Over the last  years, as government has grown, so has the Cabinet Secretaryrsquos role as a constitutional . He ndash no ldquoshe yet ndash advises the Prime Minister on constitutional issues and questions of propriety, as well as maintaining the good order of Cabinet business and co-ordinating departments. Often, though not always, he has been Head of the Civil Service too.:Agenda: How to overcome the challenge of online studyingThere is therefore good reason for the common background of most Cabinet Secretaries to include formative service in the Treasury, and senior, repeated exposure to No, often as Private Secretary to one or more Prime Ministers. They know about Parliament, the economy, cross-Whitehall management, and political and media realities. With a mainly diplomatic background, Mark Sedwill has lacked his predecessorsrsquo grounding in our curious constitution: this must have been a challenge. Eventhose appointing his successor want a revolution in Whitehall, it would be goodhe or she thoroughly understands the constitutional arrangements to be overhauled, within which crises are bound to happen. Not least, in an increasingly scandal-prone world, the Cabinet Secretary should have a neutral authority to make judgments on erring ministers and officials that command respect across the political and public scene. Letrsquos hope these are the aims.George Fergusson is a retired senior diplomat

title: come-clean-now-chores-home
story: Tony Blair revealed this week that he has not done a tap of housework since , the year he entered Downing Street to the strains of Things Can Only Get Better. Not for his we, Cherie, apparently. His excuse  He had ldquothe whole security apparatus around him, he told the Sunday Times, and le just changed. It reminded me of Peter Mandelsonrsquos story about post-ministerial le when he would jump in the back of a car and be amazed that it did not go anywhere.:Alison Rowat: From PM to First Minister, theyrsquore in this together nowMr Blair still does no housework, leaving it to ldquoCherie, the kids because he is too caught up in running his Institute for Global Change, or whatever he calls his make busy work. No matter that she has a career of her own as a lawyer, his time is still deemed too valuable to get his hands dirty with domestic tasks.Mr Blairrsquos confession was soon seized upon by the chatterati. He makes me look good, said one gleeful male columnist. Another recalled the day he left dirty dishes by the sink and his we, in turn, left him.What does it say, other than something depressing, that this fusty old debate about housework is still going on  A study by University College London last year found women still do most of the chores ndash  hours a week, six for men ndash even with both partners in full-time jobs.You donrsquot have to wander very far to see other signs that the great feminist revolution of which some of us dreamed is stuck on pause. We read, courtesy of Carl Bernsteinrsquos reporting for CNN, of Donald Trump telling former PM Theresa May she was ldquoweak and ldquolacked courage. He called German Chancellor Angela Merkel ldquostupid.Let us not forget that The Donald got his job despite the way he treated women . Or that the current occupant of Downing Street refuses to tell the public how many children he has.Elsewhere, one writer declared feminism dead on hearing the news that Kim Kardashian ndash she flogs make-up and her lestyle, mrsquolud ndash had become a billionaire. A comedian, Katherine Ryan, confirmed what everyone knew, that television  games are unbearably laddish, hence her refusal to go on Mock the Week.The Covid- pandemic looks set to make women worse off in general. A UN policy paper published in April said ldquoeven the limited gains made in gender equality in the past decades were at risk of being rolled back. It noted that women were doing more unpaid work their economic position had worsenedand domestic violence had increased.Time for feminism to have a makeover, perhaps, to remind us why its ideas are needed now more than ever. Ornot a makeover at least a sisterly whisper in the ear.As serendipity would have it, there is a crash course in feminism, of the American iety anyway, arriving on television next Wednesday in the shape of a new drama, Mrs America. Created by Dahvi Wallerand starring Cate Blanchett as Republican and anti-feminism campaigner Phyllis Schlafly, it is the true story of the fight to amend the US constitution to ensure equal rights for women and men. Wince along as Schlafly, an expert in nuclear weapons, is asked to take notes at a meeting because shersquos the only woman present.Reel as she tells a Congressman: ldquoIrsquove never been discriminated against. I think some women like to blame sexism for their failures instead of admitting they didnrsquot try hard enough. .Slick, smart, and packed with acting talent, Mrs America digs up some of the arguments against feminism, the likes of which you can still hear today.:Alison Rowat: Too many are suffering, time to get Scotland back in businessThere is a moment when Schlafly asks an audience of women whether feminism will leave them better off, or just with more work to do.Any woman who has spent lockdown juggling a job, home schooling, and all the usual chores will say an amen to that proposition. They might agree with her, too, that feminism has tended to look down on womenwho choose to stay at home and care for children rather than join the  to .Admittedly, it can sometimes feel as though the only gains to have been made in feminism are surface ones, easily erased when times get tough. It has often been that way: see the two world wars. I look at the younger women of today and they are still underpaid and undervalued still afraid to claim their place in society as the equal of men still afraid to walk home alone at night. If this is progress it looks dishearteningly modest.Yet I also see the likes of the #MeToo movement and think of old Harvey behind bars. I see women going to court to enforce their employment rights. I see them speaking up, determined not to take the same sexist nonsense we often did. Saying you are not a feminist today is distinctly uncool. Women are out there, holding down jobs, looking after children and elderly relatives, keeping a home going. And they are doing so with partners by their side.Irsquom enough of a vintage to remember when it was a rare sight to see a man pushing a pram in the street. Poor soul, must be widowed. Doing housework  Men were more likely to walk on the moon. Yet what do you know, those people, that generation, had children of their own. They did things dferently, and bit by bit progress was made. A good parent of whatever sex changes nappies, pulls their weight domestically, offers support and love in all sorts of ways. All thanks to those parents determined to learn from the mistakes and omissions of the past.:Alison Rowat: Americas rabble-rouser-in-chief hits the road againWhether you are a washed up Prime Minister like Tony Blair or not, doing nothing around the house is nothing to boast about.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.News from trusted and credible sources is essential at all times, but especially now as the coronavirus pandemic impacts on all aspects of our lives. To make sure you stay informed during this dficult time our coverage of the crisis is free.However, producing The Heralds unrivalled analysis, insight and opinion on a daily basis still costs money and, as our traditional revenue streams collapse, we need your support to sustain our quality journalism.To help us get through this, wersquore asking readers to take a digital subscription to The Herald. You can sign up now for just pound for two months.If you choose to sign up, wersquoll offer a faster loading, advert-light experience ndash and deliver a digital version of the print product to your device every day. title: letters-keep-visitors-safety-demands
story: The people most at risk of contracting the virus from tourists would presumably be those who are heavily involved in the tourist industry, such as hotel, shops and visitor attraction workers, and all who live in popular beauty spots, such as seaside towns on the Clyde coast. Given that Councillor Gallagher writes from Largs, I would have expected him to appreciate the First Ministers determination to protect the health and wellbeing of his constituents, along with the rest of the population.Ruth Marr, Stirling.MAY I put a question to Alex Gallagher  Let us concoct a fantasy that Labour in Scotland is still a political force of some consequence, and that the Government now sitting in Holyrood is a Labour one. In this fantasy, everything  ndashTory government in Westminster with Boris Johnson as Prime Minister, Covid pandemic still very much in being ndash is the same as todayrsquos actual reality. In such a situation, would Mr Gallagher not expect Scotlandrsquos Labour government to put the case for Scotlandrsquos receiving UK Government funding according to its particular requirements  Andit did so, would he describe this as ldquobegging Derrick McClure, Aberdeen AB.ALLAN Sutherlandsuggests that the First Minister should take a ferry over to Northern Ireland to find out ldquohow they used their shaky devolved powers to overcome what were told is the biggest crisis to face the UK since .Might I suggest one reason, appertaining to geography: that their neighbourhas suffered . deaths per , of their population from Covid-, compared to the UKrsquos  per ,. In contrast, we know that Covid- cases in Scotlandrsquos neighbour, England, have been ldquothe worst in Europe, just above Spain, to quote the BBC on June .Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.IN several letters recently Rev Dr Robert Anderson seems to want to vent a great deal of real anger and anathema towards the First Minister and the Scottish Government in general.It makes me wonder which Bible he is reading such is the strength of what may be described as his vitriolic prose and sentiments. .From a gentleman who is clearly very knowledgeable about the Bible the nature of the prose and sentiments seem very surprising and concerning.For example such apparent anger is totally negated by John  verses  to  where mercy, grace and forgiveness are seen in abundance.There may be reasons for Dr Anderson wishing to "cast the first stone", but the Christian ethic teaches the exact opposite of this and we should all try to state our opinion with humility and kindness.Linda C Park, Stirling.THE US has bought up most of the coronavirus drug Remdesivir in an "international heist".As the Westminster regime now aims to secure a great trade deal through the Special Relationship after Brexit, one can now point out to whose sole advantage that will be.John Edgar, Kilmaurs.

title: letters-communities-look-ways-cashing-campervans-not-banning
story: Irsquove been passed a letter signed by the chair of the Glencoe Community Council, a document that has been sent to community councils in Scotland suggesting a ldquocollective approach to the problem we all suffer from ndash over-tourism.The basis of this approach is to ldquomake it illegal to park overnight in any place other than a proper campsite. The objects of ire are campervans.I would agree there are issues to be resolved, but the character of tourism has changed dramatically in recent times.Many campervanners donrsquot want to stay in campsites because they lack the flexibility the modern tourist wants. Traditional holidays on campsites were planned in advance and people spent the entire holiday in one place. That doesnrsquot suit todayrsquos active travel market.Campervans offer people the chance to visit and explore areas of Scotland. They just need somewhere to safely park for the night ndash a non-muddy, level stretch of ground.Many campsites are now charging upwards of pound-pound a night and these five-star set-ups are greatyou want all the facilities on offer. Better to have a network of -star budget campsites ndash the corner of a farmerrsquos field, for example.Also, most campsites only open between Easter and September.There are a number of alternatives to campsites already in existence and more enlightened communities have set up overnight parking areas for campervans for a small fee. I have used such facilities in Kinlochbervie, Findhorn, the Glen Coe ski area and throughout the Western Isles.Rather than suggest "banning" camper vans from overnight parking can I suggest community councils look at ways of helping to create an infrastructure that will provide safe, low-cost overnight parking whilst creating a source of income for the communities themselves  We only have to look at the success of the Aires network in most European countries to realise that here in Scotland we are decades behind in how we treat this kind of tourism.Campervans already provide a considerable amount of money to rural economies. Owners buy fuel for their vehicles, eat and drink in local restaurants and pubs and buy supplies from supermarket and small village shops. In a country that claims to be progressive I find it extraordinary that community councils should actively oppose camper van tourism.Making informal camping by camper vans illegal would require a major change to UK traffic law, so that is extremely unlikely. Far better for community councils to work together with organisations like the Campervan and Motorhome Professional Associtionto develop a more positive, welcoming and beneficial way forward, to Scotlandrsquos benefit.Cameron McNeish, Newtonmore.

title: lotus-sports-car-created-new-cinema-aims-revitalise-highland-town
story: Now a Lotus sports car is being specially commissioned as part of a new cinema, which the serial entrepreneur behind the project hopes will help boost a Highland townrsquos lockdown recovery.Millionaire businessman Angus MacDonald has footed the entire cost for an independent cinema in Fort William, as a ldquogt to the Lochaber area where he grew up. The town has been without one for  years.Mr MacDonald, who now lives in Roshven, near Arisaig, says research had shown that the two things that can help regenerate struggling high streets are a cinema and a book shop.He opened the Highland Bookshop three years ago in the town centreand says the business has ldquoflourished.The new two-screen cinema will screen  films a day opening with the same blockbuster films as Londons Leicester Square, according to the businessman. It will also include an -seater restaurant and events space, which he hopes will boost tourism and help draw local people back into the high street.It is also thought to be the first cinema in the UK to incorporate a real car into the seating area for an authentic ldquodrive-in experience."I wanted to give something back to the town."The businessman was staying tight-lipped on the design of the Lotus, which will be unveiled two weeks before the cinema opens in mid-September.Lotus has previously found success in Formula One racing, via Team Lotus, and the cars famously appeared in the James Bond movies The Spy Who Loved Meand For Your Eyes Only .Mr MacDonald made his money buying and selling four major Scottish companies and is also a published author. Last year he sold an Edinburgh-based waste management firm in a reported pound. million deal and was awarded an OBE for services to the Highlands.: Why Scots towns are ready to fight back from the effects of the pandemicHe said: ldquoMy family have been here for a thousand years and Irsquove had a great career and I wanted to do something for my home town.ldquoI read an article in an American newspaper many years ago which said what revitalised a market town centre was an independent book shops and a town centre cinema. We opened the Highland Bookshop three years ago and itrsquos flourishing.ldquoThe next stage was the cinema and I was determined to have the best place in town and I persuaded the owner of the business on the existing site to sell to me. It is the site of the original town hall.ldquoA large part of my vision was not so much to provide entertainment for the town but for the building to become the hub of the town and to try to bring people back into the high street.ldquoI see it as more than an cinema but as a cultural centre. There will be stages to host music events and mountain biking events and such like.ldquoI always wanted it to be big enough to host Scottish Ballet or opera events."Therersquos a real opportunity for Fort William to become a cultural centre in the West Highlands.Mr MacDonald appointed Glasgow and Skye-based architect Dualchas for the project. The company was launched by identical twins, Alasdair and Neil Stephen, who wanted to help halt the population decline of the Highlands by creating more, affordable housing. They were also the first architecture practice in Scotland to develop a modern longhouse, considered the earliest structure in many European cultures.: Scotlands urban buy-out could be blueprint for townsMr MacDonald said: ldquoI wanted something very traditional. I used the old village hall in Onich as the design I wanted to follow. The cinema will have two screens, one seating  people and one for  and we will be showing the same blockbusters as Londonrsquos Leicester Square the day we open.ldquoWe also have a Lotus car being made for us which is a bit of a coup. Itrsquos a real car, everything is the same except it will be cut off behind the seats and bolted to the wall. "Two people can sit in it.ldquoThe virus has put us back about four months and we now expect to open in mid-September.Mr MacDonald said moves are afoot for further improvements to the Fort William high street, which in common with others has suffered the loss of independent businesses, becoming over-subscribed by outdoor clothing stores.He said: ldquoIf we can get  or  more shops in the high street full of things that people want to go to then the town will become much morevibrant.ldquoWe have a really good Chamber of Commerce and the mood Irsquom getting is that we can revitalise the town. We have a lot going for us, the bones of the town are good."

title: 10-000-back-petition-calling-scotlands-border-england-closed
story: Discussion has been re among politicians in recent days over border checks, after First Minister Nicola Sturgeon refused to rule out the possibility of quarantine visitors from Englandcases surge.Shestressed that there are currently ldquono plans to force visitors from other parts of the UK where virus levels are higher to self-isolate but has come under criticism for not completely ruling it out.Prime Minister Boris Johnson weighed in on the debate on Wednesday, claiming that there is no border betweenScotlandand England.:Jacob Rees-Mogg compares Nicola Sturgeon to Donald Trump in row over Scottish borderNow, thousands have backed a petition calling for the UK Government to give the devolved nations of the UK the power to close their borders to all but essential traffic.The change.org petition warns: ldquoThere is about to be a massive second wave of this new virus in England due to Tory ineptitude.ldquoThe borders of both Scotland and Wales should be closed to all but essential traffic ie commerce, not casual trips that are in fact international from a COVID hot spot about to get worse.ldquoI beseech UK Gov to give this power to the devolved nations. This is at this time imperative to save thousands and thousands of lives.Since being launched last Friday, the plea has gathered ,signatures from across the country.Jacob Rees-Mogg suggested on Thursday that Nicola Sturgeon may be modelling herself on President Donald Trump amid the border debate.He said that although it may not be a bricks and mortar structure like Trumps border with Mexico, but Ms Sturgeon wants a metaphorical wall.DuringBusinessQuestions on Thursday, Mr Rees-Mogg criticised Ms Sturgeonrsquos ldquoshameful remarks after SNP Commons business spokesman Tommy Sheppard said the Government is ldquoled by someone who thinks the border does not exist.:Coronavirus: Sturgeon refuses to rule out English quarantine amid tourism worryMr Rees-Mogg replied: ldquoHe mentions borders, and I noticed that Nicola Sturgeon wishes to have a wall ndash perhaps she is modelling herself on other leading political figures ndash between England and Scotland.ldquoBut, as my right honourable friend the Prime Minister said, there is no border between England and Scotland and it was shameful to call for a border of that type of kind to be erected to stop people travelling freely between constituent parts of the United Kingdom.ldquoOne never thought that Nicola Sturgeon would model herself on American political figures and want to build a wall ndash at least a metaphorical wallnot actually getting like Hadrian with the bricks and mortar.

title: scottish-rail-operators-performance-worst-uk
story: The new annual analysis revealed by the Office for Road and Rail regulator, found encouraging improvements being made by the publicly funded body in charge of the rail infrastructure, including tracks and signals.But it found that just .% of services arrived at their destination within five minutes of schedule, lower than the offically set target of .% which Network Rail forecast would not be met till March .Network Rail Scotland had forecast that in the two years from April,  it would be at .% and .%.The ORR also found that delays caused by Network Rail were reduced, but also failed to meet official targets.It has been revealed that Network Rails own regional scorecard based on its overall performance on a range of issues from punctuality and customer satisfaction to safety and financial management found that Scotland scored the worst of the five UK regions, marked at .% against best performer, Southern, which scored .%. Wales and Western scored .%, Eastern got .% while North West and Central got a .% mark.In November, , Network Rail was probed by the transport regulator as it emerged that it was responsible for two in three of the delays which saw ScotRail forced to settle , successful claims from passengers in nine months.And in March, last year, the Herald revealed senior managers in charge of Scotlandrsquos rail network would have their earnings slashed by regulators for the first timepassengers continued to suffer severe disruption.The regulator said that Network Rail Scotlands strongest performing areas were in safety, investment and asset management.But it scored down because it did not achieve its targets for train service performance, customer satisfaction, reduction in works complaints and other management.There were . minutes of delay per km of train travel in - - . minutes worse than official targets.ORR said: "While the reliability of Network Rail Scotlandrsquos infrastructure is improving, it is important that it focuses on other areas where the proportion of delay remains high. Network Rail Scotland knows it must do this and has recently put in place plans and dedicated resources to help reduce delays associated with its operational management of the network."Network Rail Scotland is specically focused on reducing the level of lsquounexplainedrsquo delay by investigating the worst performing routes to better understand the factors impeding performance."Network Rail Scotland experienced more earthworks failures in - than previous year, but also higher rainfall.The pattern of failures was dominated by two distinct peaks including flooding in August which closed the railway between Linlithgow and Edinburgh Haymarket.And in early , incidents included a landslip between Dumfries and Kilmarnock and the closure of the railway between Stirling and Perth after Network Rail Scotland engineers found damage at the Mill OrsquoKeir viaduct, as part of their proactive severe weather management protocol.While Network Rail Scotland registered a better performance in a number of safety related areas, ORR has identied that worker safety requires improvement, with Network Rail Scotland failing to reduce the number of minor injuries, especially slips, trips and falls among workers.The regulator issued two national improvement notices concerning track worker safety in - and it said the rail body was "responding positively" to these.Where the taxpayer-funded body excelled was in financial management. It delivered poundm of "efficiency improvements" ndash poundm more than planned.John Larkinson, ORR chief executive was encouraged, saying: ldquoThis is good news for its customers and funders.Meanwhile it has emerged that work on the reconstruction Glasgow Queen Street station, Kintmore station and redevelopment of Dunbar station is about to restart after Network Rail paused major projects in Scotland during the Covid- pandemic lockdown.Network Rail has said that, despite the three month halt on the schemes, it has invested more than poundmin renewal and enhancement on other parts of the Scottish network during lockdown.Projects delivered during this period included laying of new tracks and replacing bridges on the West Coast Mainline, improving drainage systems on the Highland Mainline, and upgrading s, station roofs, level crossings and other infrastructure across the network.Lockdown changes announced by the Scottish Government have now cleared the way for a phasedof the construction sector, clearing the way for Network Railrsquos redevelopment projects to restart.Network Rail has said that the focus on the poundmQueen Street project will be the internal fit-out to the staff management suite, Travel Shop and basement area, as well as the new entrance near the corner of George Square.

story: Speaking on BBC Scotlandrsquos Reporting Scotland programme, Scotlands Justice Secretary said he wants to take a ldquoswt decision and is ldquoall for a four-nations approach.ldquoThatrsquos Itrsquos then an administrable, a political decision whether those nations want to bring these in or not, and we have to respectand wait for them to reach their decisions.Speaking on LBC Boris Johnson has urged Britons to ldquoenjoy summer sensibly ahead of the easing of lockdown restrictions on Saturday.He said: ldquoTomorrow we come to step three of the plan that I set out on May , that everybody, I think, has understood, or huge numbers of people have understood and followed very carefully and very closely.ldquoAnd itrsquos because people stuck to that plan that wersquore now able to carefully and cautiously open up hospitality tomorrow.ldquoAnd my message is really for people to enjoy summer sensibly and make sure that it all works.England has scrapped quarantine for arrivals from low risk destinations.TheDepartment for Transport announced that the quarantine policy for passengers arriving in England from ldquolower risk countries such as Spain, France, Italy and Germany will be lted.The -day self-isolation policy remains in place in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

title: french-prime-minister-edouard-philippe-resigns
story: The official statement did not say whether Mr Philippe will be replaced, or will stay on as the head of a new government.President Emmanuel Macron is seeking to boost the two remaining years of his term with a focus on efforts to relaunch the French economy after the coronavirus crisis.The reshuffle comes days after a green wave swept over France in local elections.Mr Macron saw his centrist party being defeated in Francersquos biggest cities and stumbling across the country.The reshuffle was planned even before the vote, as Mr Macronrsquos government faced obstacles and criticism before Sundayrsquos election as the virus crisis unfolded.French President Emmanuel Macron has named Jean Castex, who coordinated Francersquos virus reopening strategy, as the countryrsquos new prime minister.The relatively low-profile Mr Castex replaces Edouard Philippe, who resigned earlier in the day.Mr Macron is reshuffling the government to focus on restarting the economy after months of lockdown.

title: air-bridges-apply-scotland-can-go-holiday-abroad
story: The current -day isolation policy for peopleto or visiting Scotland remains in place for now, the Scottish Government has confirmed, despite the restrictions being eased south of the Border.As
